content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has it's issues, but once they are fixed, this game will be amazing.Quick story: You play as this guy on a plane with a child (maybe yours?) holding onto your arm. Plane crashes, some naked tribal guy takes said child, and you're on your own.Every time you start a new game the plane will be somewhere else so you wont know where you are every time. You start off with the basics, candy, beer, a fire axe, a heart monitor (that you'll never use) and food. You'll have a survival handbook that is very useful, itll tell you what to do as well as give you a way to build things like a fire or a place to sleep, even walls to keep you safe. When you hop off the plane (and taking the fire axe out of Stacy's face) you will either be greeted with sunshine or greeted by 3 naked people about to destroy you together.At this point, if you're lucky, no one will bother you. If you're unlucky however, and the naked tibal people see you and run after you, good luck defending yourself with a fire axe and some snacks (oh and pills). I love the visuals of this game, it's very beautiful. The sunshine, the darkness, all close to realistic. I love the level of darkness at night, it's just enough to hinder vision, but not enough to be annoying. The weather is pretty awesome too, the only problem I have with the weather is the rain, I got tired of this routine:1. You are cold and wet2. Get warm by fire3. Rain stops, ventures out of base/camp4. Rains again 15 seconds later making you run back to camp/base just to get warm5. See step oneOn to the enemies: I hate them. They are annoying, buggy, and overpowered at times. I would be in my camp that is surrounded by big tall walls, and suddenly *INCEPTION MUSIC BWUM*. I would look around and see no one, then suddenly a bunch of them run through the walls and runs right back out. This gets annoying, especially when they warp into your camp and hit you from below your log cabin. When you finally have the balls/girl balls to venture out of your camp/base, you see a single naked woman watching you, then walking up to you, then hits you once taking over half your health (perfect time to look at that heart monitor!!). You swing your axe at them but your attacks are SO slow that she hits you 2 times before your next swing. Other than the things I mentioned, I love the IDEA of the enemies, they watch you, study you, instead of attacking sometimes. I love the idea of stealthing around these naked people or being stalked by them. I know it sounds weird, but these elements are not implimented well in other games, I would love this open-world survival horror game to have a moment where you hear a sound and if you're lucky, you'll see one running away.The food: You have only a few choices on food that I've encountered: Candy bar, fish, rabbits, and plants. I hated that more often than not I'm being forced to stop everything just to eat a bunny. I have trouble getting the fish, they swim too far from where you can stand and fish from, meaning you have to stand and hope they swim close to you and not swim out into the ocean. Don't get me started on the sharks in the ocean, they spawn a safe distance, SOMETIMES, once they spawned right at the edge of the water, you can't go in without being eaten. Honestly the hunting, other than the tech issues, is amazing compaired to other games. To fish (at the moment you must find a sharp spear, can't make it yet) you get a sharp spear and go look for the ocean or a pond. You stand over the fish and stab them, making them stick to your pole. This is amazing, it's small but it's great that you don't just go up to a fish and press "take". To hunt (there are only rabbits to hunt and eat at the moment) you either grab your fire axe and start running after them and swinging away, or you make a rabbit trap. The building: I love the fact that you can make yourself a camp and stay safe. When you look at your survival guide, you can build walls, cabins, steps, a tree house, and other things. They keep you safe from those naked people that want to sacrifice your body to the "Bieber" they keep seeing in the magazines on planes. I love that if you build a fire, they will come and try to kill you. If I were a tribal naked person and this guy that was in a plane crash made a camp out of 50 logs that are bigger than him in less than 2 days all by himself, I would avoid him completely.The game is in development, so there are some bugs that I've run into, here is a list of a few:-Gets killed by a naked Leelo and I wake up in a cave surrounded by 3 more naked girls and gets pummeled by them almost instantly. This isn't normal, you have a bit more time than that to recover.-End of the level, missing textures, trees in water, a message that says you can't go this way yet, it's not available in this version of the game". When that happened, I was staving looking for fish in water, and never saw one for miles.-Made a big base with large walls and stuff to keep safe, but a bunch of enemies run straight through it and attack me.-I suddenly start swimming while I was cutting down a tree, I am able to slowly swim off into the sunset above the ground and over the trees. Felt great but it was a game-breaking bug, I can't save and come back, the glitch will still be there.-I walk into a cave, start slowly rising upward, looks like I'm swimming then suddenly dropped from a high place and dies.All in all, I loved this game, it needs a lot of work but if they continue to build it even after the alpha is released, it would turn out to be a outstanding game. I recommend this game because it has potential to be a epic game, if they put love and care into it.Suggestions (keep in mind these are probly added by the time anyone reads this):-I want to make a strong spear, adding a utility knife would make things a lot easier, you can cut the sticks to make a spear-More things to hunt. This is more than likely added very soon.-Don't make caves seperate than the main world. Every time you go into a cave, the world outside isn't there anymore, causing issues with framerate and crashes.-A story. Surviving is it's own reward, but where did that kid go? Did they mistake him for their idol "Bieber"?-Random events: Imagine this, you are walking in the forest, you hear a sound, you look around but see nothing, then when you turn to look in front of you there's a guy and he grabs your neck or tries to stab you, QTE moment. Or imagine this, you made a base, heavily fortified with big walls. One night you are eating your rabbit with a side of Butterfingers when suddenly you hear some chanting. You look over your wall and see a bunch of naked people with a very large log making their way to your wall, threatening to knock it down. Events like this make the game a LOT more fun and random.I hope you enjoyed my review, thanks for reading! <3

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I always find hard to review a game I adore. I fear not to give enough credit deserved and every word is carefully picked in order to show what the said game is about and why it should be purchased.I will start off by telling why The Forest shines brighter than other survival games. I always found frustrating the neverending material farming in similar titles, days spent chopping, cutting, slashing just to build a very small hut that would get destroyed in a blink of an eye. The Forest is different. While it still takes time to craft something, you don't have to spend an entire day gathering resources. There are many available structures, with many functions (some structures having more than one fuction, as they can be extremely versatile).Another typical feature of a survival game is the how-to-spend-the-night moment. I've always seen that moment as the one where you try to stay safe, where any lurking threat has to be avoided until you get a proper equipment to fight back (if you can fight back at all). In The Forest, with a proper strategy, you can drive away the cannibals (the main enemies) even from the first night. Hoping to have given proper credit to this game so far, I'll now start listing what I personally find extremely splendid about it:  Enemy AI:  The cannibals are extremely intelligent, and their behaviour constantly develops following your gameplay; if you try to avoid them, they will look at you with curiosity, studying your movements without harming you. If you show an aggressive behaviour they will strike with an increasing force, calling for help and attacking your base weakest spots. If you are merciless they may end up fearing you, whereas if you spare some of them, they will respect you, seeing you as a godlike figure.They have multiple strategies as well: they send scouts to check your base and equipment, plan surprise attacks in the day, build different totems around to inform the others (there are lots of totems, each of them with a different purpose) or to summon special enemies (mutants).  Co-Op mode:  This is the real way to play The Forest in my opinion. Grab your friends and start playing together; the voice option (you can communicate with your real voice through an in-game Walkie Talkie) adds up to the immersion, and your voice can actually lure cannibals as they can hear you too. You can also trade items, in case a friend is in need of a particular resource; you can organize turns and roles thanks to this. Building, fighting and surviving with your friends is an incredible experience in The Forest, it's extremely fun and addictive!  The story:  The storyline plays an important role in The Forest, and gives you an exciting purpose to venture the island to find your lost son. As you crawl into the caves, sail the sea or climb the mountains you will find details of what's going on, or what happened before your arrival. There's always something to find, from creepy to disturbingly fun discoveries.  Updates:  I believe that this is the most updated Early Access game every played. There's always a new planned update that adds so many new features and fixes bugs (once you start the game there is a countdown to the next update), and it makes The Forest a title that you cannot stop playing as there will always be something new. A big kudos to the devs for this!  Optimization: Yes, the game is demanding in terms of minimal requirements, however I'd like to highlight the optimization aspect. I run this game on two PCs, a not-so-high-end laptop (which barely meets the minimum specs) and a potato desktop. I can perfectly run on medium settings on the former (without fps drops or stuttering, and on high settings with some small stutter in tense moments of fight), and low settings on the latter (without fps drops) and still looks amazing! You can run The Forest with the setting you like and it will still have a beautiful look.The price of the game should be tempting as well. For that ridiculous sum you get an amazing survival game (I dare to say, the best so far) in constant development, with a dev team that actually listens to player's feedbacks and seems to be more excited than us to work on this project. It's an Early Access game but it already has more content that most of the "finished" titles.Grab this game and I am sure you will NOT regret it!

Early Access Review
								Day 42:    I have established several camps around the island. Some are well fortified and if the natives choose to attack on a large scale these locations will surely be the choices for my retreat. I can't decide if they are all part of the same clan or if the "Shiny Ones" and the "Mutations" are seperate from the others. From what I have seen so far, this group is the only that dwell under ground through out the cave systems. To date, I have never seen the surface group enter the caves. I have witnessed on multiple occasions, openly violent attacks on the "Dwellers" from the "Surfacers" leading me to believe they are seperate. Of course this is only speculation.     Having the multiple camps has proven a must. This has allowed me to travel to the farthest reaches of the island in search for clues of my son's where abouts. I can only speculate on the accuracy of these findings as well as the location of my son.     From what I have seen thus far. I am holding out hope that he still lives. I have found pieces of his toy figure leading me to think he is leaving clues in hope that I still breathe and am in search of him. He is correct. I will tear down this island from shores to mountains until I have exhausted my options........ Or my life.    I fear to speak of the other things I have seen.  Clearly, as an attempt to ward off either myself or the creatures, from their villages.These surfacers are readily willing to set up effigies of mangled, mutilated, severed body parts of the copses from the crash. I can only hope that for their part, the victims were deceased prior to these savages locating them. From what I can tell, they have not, I'll say that again, They Have Not eaten any human flesh that I know of. However, as for the cave dwellers,......... well let me only say that I have a stronger constitution then I had thought.     It's going dark and I must prepare for the nightly hunting from both the surfacers and the dwellers. They seem to prefer the evening for killing. Make no mistake though, if you find this journal.... If I do not find my son and I am fallen, do not trust the day anymore than the night. They want blood.... for what ever reason. I can hear their calls off in the distance now and the sun has lost its' hold. I must prepare.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a survival game enthusiast, this one has been on my radar for some time now. Last week, I finally decided to pull the trigger on the purchase as one of my buddies had the game and hadn't touched it in a while; he thought it'd be good fun to hop back on and fool with co-op. One thing turned to another, and now we have our whole teamspeak server on a co-op world playing together. The game is honestly a BLAST to play with the current content in it, and is only readily improving with the quick flow of updates from the devs at Endnight Games. It's a good one to go home, blow down a fatty and just chill and laugh at the hilarious antics that come with this game while at the same time being too afraid to walk down your dark hallway to get to the bathroom after playing. This game gifts you with those little moments of bonding and hilarity; in no other game have I had such a compelling moment as when one of my buddies accidentally pushed a log sled off the ciff and onto the roof of our base, frantically screaming "LOG SLED ON THE ROOF LOG SLED ON THE ROOF" as if it were a major event, while the rest of us flew out of the base to investigate the calamity which turns into a channel wide chant of laughter. I'd like to see more enemy types, more craftible items, more light sources, more creatures (meaning neutral animals; snakes, horses, bears bugs etc). Normal mode seems to be too easy, I get the best enjoyment out of hard mode as it is significantly less forgiving, especially in large groups. As time passes by in the game, I find my base draws more and more cannibals towards it, their mechanic is very interesting as they seem to attempt to follow you around. Meaning if you leave your base for X amount of time, the result will be X amount of time in which you will have peace before they begin to seige your base again upon return. My most recent encounter on hard mode had me face to face with eight "Leader" class cannibals, and trust me when i say it is a testiment to take down even one of those bad boys. We won't even go into the other creepy beasts in the world, discover them and cry in fear.  The game definitely feels enjoyable for the long haul. It has a bit of a rust-esque grinding/building system. If we're being honest, that mindless grind for resources is one of my favorite aspects of games that fall under this catagory, so I found no issue in spending hours upon hours cutting trees, hauling them back to my base, and repeating. The game definitely feels rewarding as well, If you decide to brave through one of the (8 or 9?) large cave systems with only the measly lighter or plastic flashlight as a light source and primitave weaponry, The game pays for it for you in giving you the ability to collect rare and otherwise impossible to find/craft items; one example being the Modern Axe. I won't spoil anything but fair warning: You may or may not♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants in shear terror upon descending into the depths. The build system is solid and there is only room for improvement. It is exactly how the description of the same states it - you can build pre planned buildings, such as small or large cabins; or you can let your imagination run wild and utilize the custom objects feature and build anything from Squidward Tentacles' house to a scale replica of Rome (almost lol). I personally am in the process of building a base which is hanging off of the edge of a steep cliff on the west/southwestern coast of the map.There are many beautiful spots for you to decide where to hunker down. Overall I have highly enjoyed the time spent on the game so far and I look forward to spending much more time on this game. Development is active and there is even a timer on the main menu that identifies when the next update will come out. Would recommend.9/10

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Forest is currently an Early Access Survival Horror game. The core concept and execution of the game are excellent thus far. The Developers for this game are very active in the community and regularly release updates. Detailed breakdown:What we know about the Story:The story is in development. This means the whole Story is not there. You cannot "beat" the game as is. While exploring the island you will find clues as to what happened to "Timmy" (who is assumed to be your son). Parts of his toy, pictures, cave sketches. The game has basically zero handholding and refuses to point you in any direction at all. Most people will never find all the hidden story components. If you do find them, you will learn where "Timmy" has been takenGameplay: The game is played in First Person. The core aspects of the game are survival based. Hunger, Thirst, Rest, and Energy all make an appearance. You must hunt for food (or forage, alternatively), drink water, and sleep. So far, the survival aspects are pretty well balanced, and always being improved upon. You are going to establish a "base" or camp of sorts. Shelters, fires, walls, traps, gardens, resource management, and food storage all come into play here. There are quite a few creatable structures/devices already, and more are going to be added. Base creation takes time. You must gather resources to build things. Many people feel this is "grindy" but I enjoy it a lot. You will find yourself collecting rocks, sticks, logs from trees, leaves, and other objects and transporting them back to your base. This takes time, but seeing your base take shape feels extremely rewarding. Combat is a necessary part of the game. You are stuck on an island populated by cannibal tribes. Hungry cannibal tribes. There is so much to say for the AI in this game. They are already impressive and quirky and only getting better. The cannibals are currently broken into three tribes.Starving/Skinnies.  These cannibals are very thin/lanky, often naked and covered in blood. They are almost always hostile to the player and have even been seen killing and eating fellow cannibals. Often acting as scouts, it is common to see solo skinnies roaming the island. When they find something of interest (deforestation, foreign structures, you) they will often hide and observe for a while. When satisfied, they will run back to their camp and alert fellow cannibals. If they located your base, expect to see patrols coming and going from now on. Skinnies are the weakest of all the cannibals, but they are EXTREMELY fast and agile. It is very easy for skinnies to dodge your attacks and get behind you when in combat. Cannibals. The regular cannibals look like normal humans, with a few skin tones, often covered in dirt or decorations. They usually travel in groups of 2-4. They are not always hostile to the player, but it's always safer to assume they are. If they know your location it's common to see them roaming around the edges of your base. they are slower than skinnies but they usually carry clubs and hit much harder. They are prone to splitting up in combat, flanking and coming from behind the player. Cave Cannibals. Gray skinned aliens, basically. Stronger than regular cannibals but a bit slower. use the same tactics and skills as above. The AI is so awesome. They stalk you, they observe you, leave effigies outside your base (body parts on sticks) to mess with you, ambush you, scare you. You will find yourself fearing them, looking over your shoulder when doing even the simplest things. there are special varieties of mutants deep in the caves, but I'll leave that for you to discover.All in all this game is excellent. The core concept and foundation are very well done. The developers add more and more, and try to stay on top of glitches and bugs. More is being added and the game is only 14.99 on Steam. 10/10 for me, I love this game and would recommend it to anyone.EDIT:I have been playing this Multiplayer with a buddy of mine and it's amazing. This game is 10x better with a friend. We've had so much fun and I recommend anyone who enjoys it to try it with some friends. Beware though, the difficulty is increased for multiplayer. 11/10EDIT 2:I feel I need to take a moment to commend the Devs on this game. For a two man team (now 15-17 man team as the dev pointed out) they put an insane amount of work into this. There is an update timer on the main menu and anytime they go past the scheduled time, they always explain what happened and why. Every time they release an update there is always a hotfix for most of the new bugs the update causes within a day or two. This Dev team is literally a personification of what Early Access should be. They are such a great team and they really take the wishes of the community to heart. You will not regret the purchase, and these guys deserve support. Thank you to the Devs!

content:
Posted: January 27
Early Access Review
								Everything I do in The Forest feels like a big deal, so when things get crazy (and they really do) it is pretty mind blowing. I think that the mix of realistic, survival game mechanics and fantasy horror work great together. The Forest pushes you beyond the point of most other games. Which results in an extremely immersive and exhilarating experience. There are points in The Forest where the realistic and more fantastic elements come together beautifully. The developers of The Forest are not messing around, they will surprise you. There are some genuinely talented people working on this game.I have no problems with performance running it at 1080p and 60FPS. This game is beautiful and there is an extensive graphics options menu. The sound design is impressive too and I would recommend that you experience it in 5.1 surround. In addition to the single player experience there is also a co-op mode. I didn’t play this part of the game much but I did try it. Everything worked fine when logging into a game and there seem to be a fair few people online. The developers of The Forest have become known as a dedicated and reliable team. They have done some fantastic work here and continued to add regular improvements. The game is still just an early access title but it’s one of the best games that I’ve ever played. I would highly recommend that you buy and play this game. Let’s give the developers loads of money, so that they can continue producing amazing content.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								(Last update was July 22nd, 2014)If there is one thing I would tell Dean Hall about his Survival game "DayZ" is that I don't see the point of surviving when you are just shooting everyone in sight.  When I think of a survival game I think about a band of people coming together to overpower whatever the hell is on the planet and to fight back against it, as well as to survive and get food, and then I would hit him over the head with a sledge hammer and tell him to do his game right.PROS:The Island: When I started it up I was plopped into a jet with a kid next to me, pretty much KOed, then we started divebombing towards the ground and crashed, with some naitive guy coming and taking the child, then me getting up a hour or so later with bruises and cuts, so I grabbed everything and ran outside to see what happened.  Well the plane is cut in half and the back half where I was at is broken to high hell except the body.  I must say that the island looks really nice, and actually looks like a Forest, not just a place I got dropped into and expected to win at.The Cannibals: These guys are creepy, and actually act like a tribe which kind of threw me off, I was chopping some trees down with my little Hatchet, and all of a sudden 3 of them came up to me, I was actually kind of terrified cause I had no clue what they were going to do, so I just stood there and stared, they started to get in closer and closer, so I readied myself for a fight, then they all ran away like they just saw a ghost.  The creepy thing is that they try to surround you and flank your sides which I really didn't think they would do for how early this game is.  Also, has anyone else noticed that the silouette of a bush looks like a human? Keeps scaring me thinking someone is there.A Interactable Environment: If you noticed I said in the last pro "Chopping some trees" I wasn't kidding, you can ACTUALLY cut down every tree on the island, which is really cool feature since you can actually chop down bushes for leaves, break suitcases for items, the trees down for logs for your shelter, it's really neat, I didn't think they would go this in depth.Easily find your house: Once you make a hut, log cabin, etc, you'll get a icon on your hud showing you where the house is at, which I admire, that way I can go explore all I want and easily find my way back to the house, cause with me and my Adventurous nature I tend to get lost a lot and that icon is very nice so I can find my way back to my house.Molotovs are OP as hell: Not kidding, a Molly can kill 3-4 of them as soon as the fire touches them.  I was building my hut on the beach since they couldn't flank behind me and had only 1 way to get to me, well a group of 3 came right up to me and I froze again, I was kind of afraid to move cause I had no clue what they would do, then 3-4 more came up behind, first thing that came into my mind was "F$#k me..." I looked into my inventory and realized I could make some molly's, so I made a few and started to toss them at the group, 1st molly hit 2 in the first group, the 3rd guy ran back towards the others, I threw a second at the other group and caught 2 more on fire, the 2 that survived ran off.  So if you get cornered, Molotovs are the way out.Missing passangers(?) (Spoiler warning): I realized I was the only one on the plane in the back end, but I figured there were more than just me and a kid, so as I was wondering the island I found a hole near the beach that led to a cave, I figured "Eh what the heII, I may as well look inside." I threw up my lighter and walked around, I couldn't see much other than some suitcases and a rusty hatchet, I took the hatchet (Which does more damage than the red little hatchet.) Turned around, and looked up, there was about 30-40 bodies hanging upside down in the cave which scared the s^%t out of me, I realized I found most of the passengers on the trip it would seem...Weaponry: Other than the molly's, you get a hatchet, then later I found the Rusty Hatchet in the cave, I don't know if the Rusty Hatchet does more damage (i'm assuming it does), so you may want to find it.Effigy's: After I had killed some of the members I had dismembered them, and got their bodyparts, I thought "The f^#k am I supposed to do with these?" I figured I would make a effigy out of them like the book said, and I Just put it near my house and just kind of left it there, some more naitives came after me there was quite a large group, I didn't have enough cloth for more mollys so I lit the Effigy on fire and they all backed away and ran, I guess the effigys show you aren't to be f**ked with.Inventory system: I really liked this, it organizes things when you open your inventory and show's how much of what you have for what item, like 50 leaves, 10 candy bars, etc, and you can craft items together, like me making the molly's it's just with a beer bottle and a cloth and you are good to go!Performance issue fix: They fixed a lot of performance problems, it does run much better than what it was when it first came out, can't wait till they fix it all though.  Although now it is running much better than it had a few weeks ago or so, so good job on that end, I can even put the shadows on High again, yay.CONS:Map: This is NOT a con, but I just feel like this has to be established, the map isn't fully used and honestly I feel like i've only found about 1/4 of the bloody map itself, so when it becomes a full map i'm gonna get lost to high hell, but I can't wait for that to happen!Draw distance sucks, same with FOV, and FPS: Not trying to sound like a d%#k or anything, but the draw distance is just terrible, litterally, you have to be within 10 feet of cases, rocks, etc. it's rediculous, not to mention the FOV (Field Of View) Is just awful, it's not Call of Juarez: The Cartel bad, but it's pretty bloody close.  Ontop of that even though it's been fixed the FPS is still at a cap of 30, which feels so weird considering with all of the close draw distance, bad FOV, everything, I think it would run MUCH better than what it is.  Thankfully they did some performance tweaks and now it runs smoother, so yay on that end.Drop a Molly on your feet: This annoyed me quite a lot, when you take out a molly, and don't use it, but try to equip something else, he just drops it on his feet, and it scared the s%@t out of me and made me run into the nearest pond, so if you are going to make Molly's then for the love of god only make 1-2 that way if you use it you won't have to worry about dropping it on your feet and run around like a idiot.No Control page: I can't really find the control page, if there is one, to check the controlls, I would like to know what buttons I have to push to do things instead of f**king something up.  I don't mind the fact it DOESN'T tell me, but i'd like to know if there is some buttons that are very useful or that I might need to use at one point or another.WHAT I THINK:This game, for a early alpha game, is REALLY good, props to those 4 people doing this, compared to other people doing survival games like Rust, DayZ, and Nether, these guys know what a survival game is about, they are even going to implement a Co-op at one point to play with friends which I can't wait for.  This game, in it's alpha stage, gets a 8/10, there are some really annoying things but those are gonna get patched out quite quickly now, and it's worth every penny I spent, honestly it's half the cost of DayZ and I feel like i'm getting more.

Early Access Review
								The Forest is an experience unlike anything else you will find. In the 40+ hours I have put into it I have yet to be bored. There is always something to do, and there is always a pack of cannibals ready to drag you into their cave and make you their play thing. The Forest is in Alpha and there are bugs, But what you need to understand is unlike Day Z the developers for this game care about you the player and the game they are working so hard to make whole. The Devs actively take what the players say seriously and have continually given us what we want. I am not someone who actively supports Alpha / Beta releases if I have to pay for them, but The Forest deserves all the funding it can get.If there was ever a game to back this is it. 10/10 and only getting better with each patch.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								My First Day in The Forest [UPDATED]     I'm sitting on a plane next to whom I can only assume is my son. I look, to my left, out the window and see clouds. Turbulence, and now the front of the plane has come off. I look back at my son, who is now rocking back in forth in his seat. We hit the ground and my son goes limp. Shortly after, I black out.       I awaken to what I can only assume is some sort of Tribesman picking up my son, and carry him away. I play dead until he leaves. When he does, I get up and notice that I am all of a sudden very hungry, and very thirsty. Amazingly, I find trays of food that seem to be unharmed from the crash. I eat three or four trays and had some soda to wash it down. No time to mourn the loss of my son. I must survive.      I walk to the front of the remaining section of plane. I find a flight attendant with an axe stuck in her chest. I removed it like King Arthur did with Excaliber. I notice I have survival guide on me. After reading through that I begin collecting resources. While bashing luggage open, I spot a light in the near distance. Upon aroaching I see that it is another tribesman, and he is running at me.      My first reaction was to charge with my axe. After a few good hits, the tribesman retreats to a tree and begins to climb. I watch as he jumps from tree to tree, slowly getting closer. He makes it to a tree close to me and pounces down, much like a tiger. I begin frantically swinging my axe, and soon he is on the ground with no pulse. I hit just one more time, and the corpse explodes into limbs and other bits. Night is now falling, I better make shelter.      With my hunters sheltler built to survival guide standards, I make fire with leaves and sticks. With my fire lit, I notice the many animals that run and fly by, even at night. Ballsy birds begin perching atop my shelter. Wielding my axe, I slaughtered all birds who dare cross me. I look back at my fire just in time to see the cutest little bunny running through and setting himself ablaze. I watched as that furry little fireball ran away into the woods. I felt that was as good as a time, as any, to go to bed and rest up for my first full day of survival.[UPDATE]     It is now my second day. I awaken to find three tribesman stading outside my shelter. Two with skulls on sticks as weapons. The third with a torch. Thinking that he is unarmed, I attacked the torch wielding man first. In hindsight, this was not a good idea. I was set a flame just like that furry little bunny I saw last night.     After passing out from the pain, I awaken inside of a very dark cave, with nothing but the lighter I had in my pocket when the plane crashed. I assume that the tribespeople that attacked me earlier brought me here. I look around and find a flare gun. Shortly after, I see another on of these tribespeople in this cave. I shoot him with the flare gun, and it lights up this section of the cave enough for me to see many bodies hanging above me.      I move closer to the tribesman that I had killed. I see a body on the table that looks like it has been disected, like some sort of biology project. Im begining to think that they have plans for me. I better get out of here before its too late.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have spent the last 4 and a half days reading through ALL of the code, and I mean all 1500+ source files from 19 compiled binaries that came with the Alpha.While the engine, its systems and all the various functions across the entire game show that it is EXTREMELY early in the games development timeline (almost to the point you could say only-just-started). HOWEVER, and this is a really big HOWEVER, hence the caps. The different core functions that create the game (Physics, AI, Crafting, Environment, Survival, Graphics) are impressive in their construction. They have used some of the top add-ins for unity to speed up the games creation and improve the complexity of several core systems, and built on top of that base to create the alpha we are playing now. It is likely the integration of these systems so that they work together in unison is the reason for the initial release delays. Likely the graphical side.The bits we really care about, Items, AI, Crafting, Survival Mechanics and World interaction are all setup in such a way that adding new things, improving current stuff or replacing parts entirely is easy from a coding perspective, thanks to the methods they use to pass information and trigger functions across entities in the game world.Most of what we are experiencing in the Alpha is what I call place-holder code. Simple versions of what the function should do once it has been developed. Just enough code so that the function will not crash the game, or another function if it is called. SO MANY functions do not even have code written for them. They do nothing when or if they are even called.Some areas are of course further developed than others. Building structures and crafting is quite fleshed out fundamentally, the AI is all ready for family based societies and most of the complex roaming and searching code is not being used. Combat is not even their really. being able to collide with things and pass functions calls allows the simplistic fighting and moving we have in the game, and I seriously think this will be replaced entirely.My guess is that the first few patches will be stability and integration patches. These will improve the functions in the areas most reported and further integrate the different add-ins with their own code, and finally customizing those add-ins further to support the game they want to create. Further content, like additional craftables and buildables, and more complex AI (like family society) will probably not come until another patch or two has past. Depending on the assets they have ready now, and the complexity of how those are used in game, we will see a handful of craftables, items or buildings added in any patch, but big content will be later. We are likely to see movement, collision, combat and item interaction improve dramatically in the next two patches, as well as performance increases and general stability.I also assume that the integration of these add ins, and customizing them would be quite complex and time consuming. Working with other peoples code can be time consuming and unpredictable until you are as familiar with that code as you would be your own. These add-ins are not simple little modules, they are advanced highly developed and quite complex systems. As time passes, the dev's will get more and more familiar with the coding of these, and development speed will increase.I found no evidence (in my mind) that suggested any aspect of what they advertised was false or misleading as far as what the game is becoming. In fact the code suggests that the game is going to be a lot more than what we know already. There are some really cool things that just are not used or spoken of at all.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game just ticks all of the boxes for me.Games like Outlast force you to experience all the jumpscares. This goes for most games that belong to the horror genre. The Forest, however, is different. You can go the whole game without encountering any of the mutants and cannibals if you play your cards right. It's only when you let your guard down that you get ♥♥♥♥ed over. Nothing makes you♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants quite like seeing the silhouette of a hunting party sprinting across a hill in the distance. I've woken up some mornings and really don't want to leave the safety of my tree house. No other game has given me that gut-wrenching feeling as to date. I feel as if i'm ♥♥♥♥ing playing Minecraft PvP all of again; holding down "sneak" for dear life and as not to get spotted. The AI in this game is fantastic. The cannibals will leave you alone for the first few days, watching your every move. As the game progresses they get more and more ballsy. The AI will test you to see how you respond. If you act fearful and run away they will see you as prey and you'll end up with more raiding parties visiting you. However, If you act aggresive then they will retreat only to return with an army that, no matter how powerful you are, you just wont be able to match. Staying neutral with the tribesmen requires maintaining eye contact, holding your ground and showing your strength. Gaining respect from the natives is crucial to your survival. I do have to poke some fun at the audio though. Whilst the atmospheric sounds are ♥♥♥♥ing on point, certain noises are just all over the ♥♥♥♥ing place. For example, when fighting a single cannibal it can sound like there are 3 more behind you when in reality there's not. Beating a native to a pulp is incredibly disorientating when screams from the same cannibal move from your left ear to your right ear even though the tribesman hasn't moved. Certain water sounds are also unbearably loud when compared to other ambient effects. Obviously the game is still in alpha and these issues will surely be resolved, but the game already feels incredibly polished already; I've yet to experience any sort of game-breaking bug.I've not played a game that made me giddy inside for quite a while. Therefor I highly reccomend "The Forest"

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 1: The plane has crashed and my son has been taken from me. Finding my son is my number one priority but I am shaken up. Just what was that who took him? I take a few moments to collect myself and gather what I can from the plane. I then walk out of the plane only to find what once belonged to my fellow tennis players. All of their suitcases, all over the ground. I take what I can and leave the crash site. I notice night is approaching. I find a small cliff and set up a small shelter with a campfire. Before I get ready to sleep I hear something out in the Forest. Like . . . moment, lots of it. I keep one eye opened while I sleep tonight. Day 2: Morning is here and I am hungry. Outside my camp I found bushes with many berries that I can sustain myself with. After finishing these berries I am ready to start looking for my son. I don't know what is waiting for me out there but for his sake I will be brave. I spend the entire day searching. Hours of searching and nothing. I notice night is approaching and run to my camp. I feel as if I am being followed and do not want to be out here at night. Night is here and I just made it back to my camp. But . . . this night is different. There is a full moon out tonight and I see people. They are just standing there . . . watching . . . waiting . . . They do not get close to my camp tonight but I sleep with one eye open again. Day 3: Mere berries will not sustain me much longer. I am hungry . . . so very hungry . . . However, I cannot let something like hunger bother me. I must find my son. He must be so scared . . . so . . . alone . . . While searching for him I came across a deer in the Forest. Half mad with hunger I pulled out my hatchet, ran up to him and started swinging. I skinned the deer and wear its hide. I return to my camp with its meat and eat like a king tonight. It is good . . . so very good . . . Before I fell asleep I noticed the men in the Forest are here once again. They are getting closer to me each night.  I don't know what they want from me . . . I sleep tonight with both eyes open. Day 4: My son . . . my son . . . it has been days now and I am starting to lose hope. I don't think he could have survived this long on his own. I have not the energy to look for him either. I am tired . . . I am cold . . . I am alone . . . I sleep tonight with both eyes closed. After only getting 2 hours of sleep I wake up in the middle of the night to find 2 men within arms reach staring at me. I slowly reach for my hatchet . . . I grab it and start swinging. A blow to the head drops one of them while the other runs off. I am covered in blood. I do not sleep any more tonight. Day 5: My son is dead. I am sure of it. I will kill everything on this island. I spend the day preparing for what is to come. I hunt down lizards and wear their skin as armor. I drag their bodies to my camp, rip the flesh from their bones, and cook them in the fire. Night is approaching. I see about 7 people in the Forest. They are watching me . . . I do not sleep tonight . . . for I . . . am watching them . . . Day 6: I am ready. I do not need sleep anymore. I spend the day hunting down small groups of these . . . animals . . . I drag their bodies to my base one by one. A stack of bodies lie in front of me. I start hacking away at them. The arms, the legs, the head. Everything can be used. I mount their body parts on sticks to let all know that I am not to be messed with. The smell of blood and human flesh fills the Forest and my camp. Night is approaching. I don't see anyone. I sleep on their torsos tonight.  Day 7: Hungry . . . Need food. I will hunt for food. In the Forest I find small group of men. I run in with hatchet in hand and kill them. All of them. I drag their bodies to base. Stack them up and chop them in to pieces. I cook these pieces and eat them. They are good . .. very very good .. . . Day 8: i am alone. .. i am enraged . .i  hungryy .... . found sleeping man in tent . dragged him to base.. ate him. he was goodDay 9: son, ware r you . son. .. .must be tasty . . . s-son .. . dont enter  … .. the Forest.............Day 10: ……7/7 Would go crazy and eat people again

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I just purchased this game a few days ago.  While I haven't accrued too many hours yet, I will post a review of my experience so far. I've been very impressed so far with the building system in The Forest.  It reminds me of the system for base construction in Fallout 4 except implemented much better.  Placed structures usually mesh nicely with terrain and allow the user to place them almost anywhere, even on top of one another.  You can mesh walls into towers into supports and other structures well to make a continuous base without ugly gaps or places where objects fail to make good contact with uneven terrain.  I've had a lot of fun just building bases with friends.The atmosphere of the game is also well done.  You start stranded on an uncharted island, awakening after a plane crash.  As you explore the island further, you find all kinds of creepy and tortured corpses of other would-be survivors of the plane wreck.  The island is also inhabited by the cannibals, which are similar in appearance to the Forsworn in Skyrim.  There is also ambiance such as wild animals and nice graphics which make the island feel alive.  Night time is very dark and you're often equipped with a lighter or a torch for visibility.  Construction of permanent lamps for your base that never burn out using skulls of slain cannibals lets you create a very homey feeling base against the darkness of the night.  It gives nice atmosphere and feels like you're stranded in a forbidding forest.  If you really hate the night, you can sleep through it, but I enjoy it.The cannibals are a constant threat against survival and they seem to attack in larger and more powerful groups as you survive longer.  Some of them can even destroy some of your walls and structures.  I like this feature, as it feels like you're making a fort to hold against a siege rather than just purely for decoration.  Some of the more advanced enemy creatures are also really creepy looking and add to the atmosphere of The Forest and its mysterious island.  I have often wondered if these were the results of experimentation carried out on other survivors in some Frankensteinian lab or something below the surface.There's also a lot of areas to explore.  You find interesting and unique things located around the island the game is centered on, and there are caves to explore too.  I haven't gotten very deep into these caves yet.  The game also, while giving a good and large map to explore with many interesting places, provides means for avoiding getting lost.  Player nametags are always visible from any distance.  Your base will show up from any distance with a marker.  Lastly, you can place flags and beacons to mark places of interest.  These features make the game navigable.Control of the game is good.  It comes with a full set of keys to remap and adjusters for mouse sensitivity.  As a left-handed gamer, this was important to me.  There is also a wide array of graphics settings to change that get quite in-depth and customizable.  The game's sound is also good.  It has all the pieces in place to make a game enjoyable, and no major things are lacking in this regard.  It's also relatively bug free, especially given it's still early access.  I would make one word of caution for this game, however.  It is a whole lot more fun with friends, and I'd recommend trying it out as a group instead of solo.  I feel that group play is immensely more fun than solo play.  I haven't tried to meet new friends on the game merely through its avenues, but it may prove difficult to network and create new friends in-game on your own as the options available are either solo play or co-op, which allows people to join the game if you invite them off your steam friends list.I recommend this game if you like survival games or enjoy games where you can build bases.  Both these aspects of The Forest are done very well.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I started up the game thinking it was going to be another DayZ/Rust Survival game clone/wannabe. I was horribly horribly wrong. 1st try: Started up, stayed at the airplane, got snatched up by the enemies, died. 2nd: ran far away from the plane, accidently ran into a patrol of enemies 3rd: found the beach, Started making a hut, Patrol saw the hut and ran into it, I was sleeping.4th: Found a beach, decided to wait and watch for patrol, found the patrol not too far away, but far enough away. Built a camp, survived a few nights while building up the camp, made some traps around the hut, expanded. Chopped down a tree without noticing a patrol nearby. They heard it, noticed the camp, ran at the camp. no one was in it, took the food in my fire and left. One stayed behind. I killed the one, next day hear a screech, ran behind a tree, watched the patrol that was there the night before race into the hut. They found their dead partner, screamed, and immedatly ran out in search of me. Fanned out running in every direction, one came across me behind a tree. I struck, he screeched and alerted his pals. I died taking down four of them. I havent encountered even half of the game yet, in the few hours I played I got immersed, horrified of every sound, and awed at the beauty of the forest and ocean. It's a great game already. Yeah it has it's bugs and problems, but it's an alpha. the important part is it's a great game from the beggining. It can only get better from here.

Me and my friend fended off the tribes people all night until the framerate dropped to about 5 frames per second due to the many many teeth/legs/arms/heads littering the floor. content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Forest isn't your run-of-the-mill early access survival game, not at all. The Forest outshines all of it's competitors, which is ironically amusing considering how dark this gem is. Enjoying this game with a friend or four is some of the most fun I've had playing recent games with pals, attemping to survive the cold, desperate nights with the constant intimidating growls and disheartening squeals of the mutant cannibal audiences gathering to watch your hopeless pantomime fall to pieces is thrilling, wild and funny as hell. When playing alone, that's when you experience the true fear this game does so well to conjure up, and you get a, to be expected, more polished singleplayer experience, so don't feel put-off if you don't have another soul to play with, I'd still highly recommend picking it up. The game is constantly being updated (as of 26/06/2016), with plently of exciting features being added and the very welcome bug fixes that make you forget you're playing an 'uncompleted' game. The enemies themselves, the cannibal hordes and hulking messes of mutated limbs all provide a fun and responsive combat experience, the 'things' you'll face in The Forest are truly disturbing, the half naked, starving, blood-covered cannibal women and the giant, baby-like belly-flopping mutants are nicely varied and each encounter leaves the adrenaline rushing and hands sweating, especially at the beginning of the game when you have nothing to defend your sorry self with but a cloth-covered rock and a walkietalkie. The Forest is a fairly well optimised, gritty and immersive true 'survival' horror experience that is well worth it's asking price, and in a sale? Bonus. Get it, for both a great singleplayer and a hilarious multiplayer experience.

The combat is also great and there are many possible tactics you can use to suppress the cannibals. Now there are a few annoying bugs here and there but nothing very game-breaking. The graphics are also INSANELY good for a game made by such a small group of people using the unity engine, it definitely makes the game much more appealing.Overall I'll give the game 8.5837/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game should be the new standard set for survival games. The first day begins gathering basic supplies: food, water, sticks, rocks, and setting up a basic shelter. It might even seem peaceful at first. Lonely, but peaceful. Then the cannibals arrive. Its the middle of the night, you wonder why sleeping only lasted through half the night as a leader and others in the night patrol encircle your pitifully undefended camp. This is one of the few games that forces you to flee in that situation, leaving everything behind. But then a new day comes! You harvest lumber, you hunt, and you build to survive. But beware, as your impact on the forest becomes more obvious, the cannibals bully you more and more. Truly a spectacular single player experience, and once more bugs are fixed, the same could be said for online play. The only reason this game isnt a perfect 10/10 is some annoying bugs, but it really does feel like a finished product to me, so final rating: 9/10

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Guess it's about time I put my 2 cents in about this game. I'll keep it relatively short whilst trying to do it justice. Do I reccomend this game? Hell Yeah!Sure it's Early Access and there are little buggy things here and there getting worked out, but updates are pretty much every 2 weeks with hot patches daily if necessary. However the enviromental effects are superb and improving all the time. I have 250ish screenshots just because as you are playing the game you just say to yourself "wow that looks amazingly realistic" and bang goes your finger to the screenshot button. Although the storyline is still developing there is plenty to keep yourself occupied (it is a sandbox type experience with survival elements). You can experiment with building bases, or if you tire of that you can go walking/exploring/rescource gathering, or diving/swimming/rafting or even caving.  At the same time you must attempt to fight off the hungry/angry natives/cannabals/mutants or wildlife, and maintain your levels of hunger/thirst/heat and health (assuming that you are not disabling this via a cheat code/or you are playing solo and not multiplayer which obviously alters the experiance).As far as graphics go, obviously as I said earlier it's really good, but to further touch on this I have to say that the textures are sharp and clear and believable even when close up, and the effects such as looking in the water (objects move and distort with the motion just like real water) the wind blowing through the trees/grass etc make a truly immersive experiance. And of course the believability is further enhanced by the sounds of animals (incl bird songs at dawn) waterfalls and seaside/ocean sounds and falling leaves/crackling fires, and of course the spooky mutant calls/breathing and muttering noises that'll keep you on your toes ready to run/fight. Of course there are some placeholder effects here and there, but it is Early Access.So what do you have to lose for the current price? You would already get more hours of playtime than loads of fully content complete AAA titles and it's only going to get better. In fact it has the potential to become one of the best survival horror sandbox games ever.I rate 8/10 current, 11/10 expected!P.S. After curiously looking to see what some people give negative reviews for, I would say this...a.) You cannot do bugger all in this game in only a couple of hours, and if you are writing a review from that experiance, you are not qualified.b.) If you have trouble surviving or evading the cannabals or having your buildings destroyed, you need to improve your tactics and not blame the game, 1000's of others seem to manage ok (my current game is at day 37), that is not to say it is totally easy, it is a survival horror after all.....and gameplay balancing/AI etc is still being developed.c.) Glitches or bugs (wtf?) Do you not understand the concept of Early Access? Instead of critically reviewing the game, post your bugs and suggestions on the appropriate forums and help this game become the masterpiece it can be. And you're also moaning about what? $15, yet would pay $80-90 for a supposedly complete title of comparible next gen quality.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day One: Plane went down in the middle of a forest on a remote island. There were only three survivors: Myself, Anthony, and Josh. We gathered what supplies we could from the wreckage; food, cans, circuit boards, and a nifty axe. After grabbing everything we could carry, we made for the coast. I don't know what direction we went. Eventually we found ourselves on the beach. It started raining and we were all freezing. It was miserable. Night came, we huddled close together against a rocky outcropping, munching on snacks and downing sodas. We weren't the smarted when it came to nutrition.Day Two: The sun came up and warmed our bodies, it was the best feeling in the world! We discovered that we were actually quite good at chopping down trees with our tiny little axes. And the trees conveniently turned themselves into logs once chopped down. We had to chase them, as they tried to roll away very quickly. Even so, we discovered that we could carry TWO giant logs at a time! We put the Mountain from Game of Thrones to shame! And we also discovered that the plane crash gave us wonderful construction skills. We had a large cabin built fit for a ski resort in no time at all. And the most wonderful gift of all: FIRE!Day Three:Found berry bushes, good thing too, our food supplies are dwindling. NOTE: DISCOVERED THAT SAID BERRIES MADE US VOMIT UNCONTROLLABLY AND DID NOT MAKE US FEEL ANY BETTER. We set about looking for more food and fresh water sources. Anthony found a lizard and roasted that sucker over a fire. Tasted terrible but filled us up wonderfully. Josh spent an hour chasing a rabbit, ended up getting lost and we had to go searching. We found him hiding in a hole and screaming that we weren't alone on this island. Anthony and I just figured he was losing his damn mind. We eventually calmed him down and got him back to camp and had some more lizard meat. Still no fresh water though, still living off of sodas. We ended up building a large bonfire with logs and sticks but ultimately failed at lighting it. Oh well...Day Four:Early morning I awoke to find that Anthony was gone. Josh and I gathered a few things and went out searching. It felt like hours before his screams echoed through the forest. We rushed to the source but were intercepted by Anthony breaking through the brush like a mad man, urging us to turn around. We did, he wasn't normally one to overreact. Josh's sarcasm♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. "Now do you believe me?" He had asked in a smug tone. I was still skeptical. Anthony was shook up bad, claiming he was abducted and taken to a cave full of half eaten humans and full of weird mutated cannibals. Whatever, these two are going nuts. I need to start planning on ways to get rid of them...Day Five:I was wrong! I WAS SO WRONG!!! These ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s came from the trees by the dozens! I had a bow with some arrouws but the damn thing was difficult to aim! I used up what I had and switched to my axe. That worked much better. These things are fast though! Josh ended up lobbing Molotovs at them and Anthony smacked them with a skull club he had made. We drove them off but suffered some nasty wounds. They'll be back, and next time we will be ready...Day Six: We weren't ready, halfway through building a defensive wall around the camp they came again. With many, many more. Anthony was taken down at the start, they mobbed him viciously. Josh♥♥♥♥♥♥himself and made for the water. I turned in time to see him devoured by a damn shark. What the hell is wrong with this place?! I am hiding inside the cabin we built, I hear the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s outside. Their screams and grunts will not allow me any sleep. I hope this isn't the end...Day Seven: I'm still alive. The cannibals are still out there, I hear them. Hell I can smell them. I dare not stick my head out the window to look. WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥!? THEY MATERIALIZED THROUGH THE WALL!!! HEEELLLLLP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Recommend 10/10Would be killed by glitching cannibal again.

Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game! not only is it graphicly stunning but so much attention to detail has been paid to the intricacies within the gameplay. The A.I. is great and has ironicly been the cause of some bad reviews because people simply haven't understood that the natives have so many different character traits and responses to your interaction with them. Sometimes you cause fear, sometimes intrigue, these natives don't act in a singular 'standard' manner. Your interaction with them and the habitat around you all contribute to the circumstances you will find yourself in.Early Access can be a minefield, I know, I have supported quite a few but I would like to point out that the developers of this game are the most hard working and dedicated team I have come across in the Early Access Genre. (If you don't believe me, go and check out their changelog for the last 12 months) As soon as you boot the game it will tell you when the next update is due (on average, every 28 days) and every update consists of a massive list of changes, fixes and tweaks.There is no good reason I can think of not to buy this game if you like the survival genre, it ticks more boxes than any other game of it's type. Even in its early access state it is fantastic!!11/10

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Considering that its Alpha stage, its brilliant.The game itself at this stage, is well worth the money....There are many types of animal to prey on, kill, skin and eat/used to craft, so far ive seen lizards, deer, rabbits, fish, turtles, racoons, birds, and boar... of which, can be used to craft/cook....With headhphones on, the game is engaging and spooky, never knowing when you might be being spied upon or spotted by the enemy, the eery noise that alerts you when you've been seen or even if they.re suspicious.... ...some of them sound like 'Lord of The Rings' Smeegle on a bad day, ...sinister giggles... footsteps in the dark... O_____O  ...Sometimes the mustants/cannibals will back off and run away, but sometimes there will be a group of them (and i believe they communicate between groups with distance between them, however it may just be me making it up in my head through in game paranoia)...they will chase you, try to knock you out...to take you to their pitch black, damp and spooky cave, corpses hanging from the ceilings...       -of which you have to (try to) escape,sometimes seemingly impossible-to-navigate cave sections, with only a lighter of which to find your way out with... which occasionally goes out, only to be re lit, to sometimes come face to face withyour captors... ...and they dont give second chances once they've caught you.The lower than expected requirements needed to run it -(considering the amount of things going on/large array of plant and animal diversity and quantity -depending on your graphical option settings-as far as plantlife is concerned), i'd assume this is down to the ability of the developers/game engine... **CAUTION**For your first few hours i'd caution you all that, until you are completely familiar with the workings of the game, you should have been to the toilet before you sit down to play, because-(...and to note,  i'm not usually easily spooked)... -there is something about 'The Forest'- that makes it stand out from others within the same genre...The fluid/ slightly tactical movements made by the mutants,cannibals and animals, with their seemingly non standard boundaries of usual survival/openworld games, alongside the noises created by animals, yourself,the enemy or background noise, the fear of being found in the first few hours...Looking forward to future updates and (minor) bugfixes, well done to the developers.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Absolutely terrific if you're into early access survival games and an absolutely terrific place to start if you're not. (TL;DR at bottom)While most would say the story mode sets it apart, it's GIGANTIC island environment, or the stunningly intelligent AI, I think what sets this game apart from others is the amount of options you have. This is key for any survival game, yet most miss out on it. With Rust, for example, you can play solo but chances are you wont get anywhere past a 2x2 home before getting raided by a group or another solo player OR you could be in a massive group, build a massive base and be touched by practically no one except other massive groups. The Forest, however, has a plethora of options to choose from: you can live on land and fight off waves of mutants, move from temporary shelter to temporary shelter and hide from the mutants, build a house boat and live on the water, or just go on a rampage and hunt down every last mutant you find(they don't infinitely respawn) to claim the island yours. And the AI is simply the best I've ever seen(if I could buy this game once if it meant one other game gets AI as good or better than this, I would not stop buying this game) They are so unique they practically amplify your options: They don't know you exist when you start, giving you a chance to have different playing styles when encountering them. They are programmed to calculate and strategize, so if one of them sees your house and runs away, just know that your security needs to be amped up. The only things I complain about with the AI are that there are no projectile shooting mutants, which makes living on the water pretty damn OP if you don't have to return to the shore at all. Another thing is that there are tribes of these mutants that do fight each other and I feel that hasn't been used enough. I hope this game does get to the point where you can befriend tribes and rival others in both single player and co-op modes. TL;DR:PROS:-Super intelligent AI(even for early access)-Options and freedom(which most early access games miss out on)-Story mode(it's being worked on but still)CONS-Optimization(pretty much the plague of every early access game. You could  just run it on low memory mode but it looks horrible)-The need/lack of tribe mechanisms(I cannot stress this enough, this would be an amazing feature if you could join tribes, rival them, etc)Final rating 9.8/10 buy this game. If it's on sale DEFINITELY buy it

number of helpful: 79 of 87 people (91%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't write reviews for no good reason, so if you happen to see this, please take time to read. This my first 8 hour impression of The Forest.I play too many survival games, its the genre of the hour these days it seems. I have problems with survival games... I love them, but they're broken, culturally in most cases and mechanically in others. I've owned The Forest for 6 months now and never put an ounce of time into it. I've played Rust, I've played Landmark, Ark, DayZ (modded well before all this alpha crap started). The list could contiune on for quite some time. I'll be honest, most days I want to go back to the time when Steam asked us to vote on "Steam Greenlight" and change my vote... but for The Forest this is not the case. The Forest is well done for an alpha of nearly 6 months, I played by myself, but not co-op yet as I don't expect much from a partially finished game, especially in a multiplayer environment. It seems there is a very interesting story developing underneath all these neat mechanics they have. Crafting is relatively easy and some of the hand-made tools make it challenging at first to figure out what the hell to do. They all seem to work to some extent though. When I played there were 4 types of housing, 4 fires and multiple tools to make, along with other stuff to do, it was enough to keep me busy in single player mode without the cannibals until I had nothing left to build. The game itself is visually stunning - runs great with minimal bugs (FOR AN ALPHA KEEP IN MIND). I expect to see them so I'm not going to ♥♥♥♥♥ about the time I fell through the world, or the time I "woke up" dead. Things I liked:*Trees fall organically, as in - it doesn't just spray you with materials... the tree falls and then explodes into logs *neat!**World looks AMAZEBALLS - even on medium settings it looks nice.*Lighting works, mostly. I expect lighting errors during development, this had... very few in the 8 hours I played. *Focus on Co-op -- from the very little I played against the cannibals... I can tell this game is going for force a cooperative experience rather than shove ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s down your throat like other survival games do. I like that.*The AI.... acts scary... as in, I was followed by a scout, who took great care to hug the bushes... first few times I thought I was seeing things... until I squarely saw him run from bush to bush.. sneaky son of a ♥♥♥♥♥... The combat was... a little bit to get used to at first as it seems the hitboxes might be off -- however its more likely that I just suck at it. Things I didn't like:*Eating and drinking are broken like in EVERY survival game - this game does a far better job of managing it than others, still I find myself wondering how one man goes through 7 lizards in one day... big♥♥♥♥♥lizards, not your garden variety "Oh how cute its a lizard" -- I'm talking Bearded dragon status...If it were a normal day, I've have eaten 7 times in 16 hours...*Climbing ropes was... awkward, you can use your lighter but not your weapon (thats odd, I have two hands..)*Explosives useage was... disappointing, dynamite for a piece of rope... c'mon... I assume this will be fixed later.*Fire does not burn nearly as long as "The Forest" name would suggest... I'm not asking for the entire place to burn down, but those 3 molotovs certainly would've brought Smokey the Bear out in my neighborhood... He didn't even know it happened here.The devs have obviously put some time and thought into this game, I'd liked to have seen more from 6 months worth of development however when you consider its basically a basement coding operation (2 guys from my understanding) I am quite impressed with what they have to offer. If you're looking for a full survival experience I am confident that when this game releases it will be one of the better versions of that experience, right now I found myself simply wanting more from the experience - more to build, more to do, more to... oh god, whats that?!    "GET AWAY FROM ME CANNIBALS!!!!!!!" Did I mention the AI is.... scary good?Although I was able to spend nearly 5 hours exploring the island... just exploring and still had a good time checking out the world they built. Some parts seem a little lifeless still but its obvious they're still fleshing this world out. I'm banking on this game being a 9/10 when it finally releases.

number of helpful: 82 of 92 people (89%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								THE MOST IMMERSIVE GAME I'VE EVER PLAYED(multiplayer thoughts, and update comments at the bottom)I've been gaming for over 30 years and I've never experienced anything quite as special as The Forest is.Very quickly, you're the lone survivor of a plane crash on an unknown island and your task is to find and rescue your kidnapped son - okay, maybe the devs lied about you being the only survivor of that crash.To do this you have to craft, build, explore, defend yourself, and survive long enough to track him down before the local cannibals figure out he's their equivalent of nice juicy veal steak. Yum yum.PROSEnvironment/Atmosphere/Mood- Very nice graphics. The flora of the woodland - from the grass and ferns to the tallest trees, and pretty much everything in between - transports you away to a rustic, lush green island and thoroughly immerses you there.- Truly pitch black conditions at night (apart from when the moon is out) and in caves. THIS is what Skyrim should have been. Navigating at night is difficult and very dangerous. Do you just sleep through the night or press on with your work?- The best caves and cave exploration I've ever seen in a game. The general design for them is great, and you truly do get a sense of clautrophobia that hightens the tension of an already scary game. Some of the caves are very long too so you have to make sure you're thoroughly prepared before you dare disappear into the blackness.- The wind blows through the forest, pushing all the leaves and bushes and creating wonderful rustling sounds all around you. You must experience it to feel how atmospheric it is!- The distant running of underground streams and the dripping of water from the ceiling create a wonderful sense of being deep in an ancient cave. The sound effects are truly great.- I was chasing a raccoon with a spear and it jumped up onto a tree and ran up the trunk to the top. How cool is that? I wasn't expecting that and it surprised me immensely (in a good way).- The best inventory system in a game I've ever seen. All your items are laid out on a sheet of tarp as if you've just emptied out your rucksack onto the ground. You can then place different items in the centre area to try and combine them into new things. This is an excellent crafting system, as you have to experiment to find out what will combine to produce what.- The cannibals make some truly disturbing noises, especially when they're asleep in the caves.Combat- Very satisfying first person combat with melee and ranged weapons, molotovs and even DIY explosives. Everything you could possibly need to get rid of those pesky cannibals.- You can craft and lay traps to capture or kill the cannibals. Just place them on the ground and then sit back to enjoy the view.Survival- Excellent survival experience. You'll have to become very good at chasing fast rabbits if you don't want to starve to death. You'll also need to be looking out permanently for sources of fresh water - I almost died of thirst during my first in-game day. Other factors to take into consideration are the cold and succumbing to illness/infection. Although these last two still appear to be in development at the time of writing.Gameplay- A free building system (similar to that in Rust) that allows you to build pretty much any kind of base you'd like.- You can build an Ewok village in the trees! :D- A survival game with a story and end game scenario quest. Moreover, not just any story; but one you will care about and will want to work towards completing. You will want to survive, adapt, and rescue your kidnapped son.- Lumberjacking is a strangely satisfying and soothing experience.- The devs have meticulously hand-crafted a large island with unique places to discover (No procedural generation here!). You really will have to work to discover quite a few of the hidden things in caves and in amongst the dense foliage above ground.Extra Info- VERY polished for an early access title.- Great value for money at the current asking price. I would have happily paid 2 or 3 times as much - even in its current state.- Very stable for early access. I've experienced only a few minor issues.CONS- It's still only in early access stage :'( - Objects that you can pick up (sticks and rocks for crafting) glow and flash - this truly does break the immersion. Please give us the option to turn this off!- Combat still lags and jerks, and also freezes for a second (this seems to be most obvious when a cannibal jumps at you). This is frustrating because you lose the flow of the fight and you'll have to spin your character around desperately looking for your attacker before they hit you from some completely unsuspected angle.- Occasionally, a cannibal will hit you and you'll go flying 100 feet into the air. The punch won't kill you, but the fall sure will.***Multiplayer Review Update***Personally, I prefer the forest in single player mode, as it gives you that true feeling of isolation on a hostile island. But multiplayer, with up to 8 people, is very enjoyable. It's definitely easier, as you can fight the cannibals together (3 of us took down a group of 5 of them very quickly) and building is much quicker. With extra pairs of hands you can build elaborate structures rather quickly.There are some bugs, however, e.g. sounds and certain textures not working/triggering properly. These seem to occur when your CoOp partners are interacting with the environment and enemies. I think it must be because of some sort of lack of synchronisation between the server and players.I've deliberately kept this part of the review short, sorry, but mulitplayer is definitely recommended. Especially if you have some good friends to run around and hack and slash with :)***10th December 2015 UPDATE***After this latest update your actions in the environment really seem to affect whether the cannibals can find you.I lit a fire (just as an experiment) and then ran away to a safe distance. Sure enough, one minute later I can see an enemy running around my makeshift camp clearly searching for who or what built it.I also started lumberjacking in a remote area - again as an experiment. Five trees later, and one stump destroyed with an explosive, and there were loads of them just flocking to where I'd been working! That put me in a lot of danger, and in the end all I could do was run away to safety, abandoning what could have been my new home.The Forest just keeps getting better and better! :)If you'd like to know more, especially about multiplayer, feel free to leave questions below and I'll get back to you.If you didn't find this helpful, do let me know why - thanks :)
