Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. It is so realistic made forest. You begin on the plane with your son and suddently your plane crashes to island with mutants and canninbals. The canninbal takes the child and your goal is to save him, but as you begin to explore and survive you begin to face the mutants, canninbals, weather changes...You can built an awesome bases around the crashed plane, on forest, on mountains, on beach and even in caves (BEWARE: Each time you save or spawn there, the mutants an canninbals will spawn too. If you build your base right between where canninbals have camps, then expect to have attacks, they will come everytime). Also making traps against canninbals is sweet idea, so you can protect yourself against them and finished them with normal or modern axe.I gaved three copies to my friends and we created a lot of bases and traps but theres more to explore :3Yes the game is in alpha stage, so expect some funny or weird bugs for example like: - Throwing TNT on the ground around 5 trees and suddently 10 more trees fall down but in the end you get a lot of logs,- Canninbals no clipping through trap when the trap isnt activated, (FIXED)- When you chop down the tree, few logs launch into air high,- Spider Mutant or Armsy Mutant destroys one part of your base but can accidently destroy other side of your base somehow. (FIXED)- Trying to hit canninbals while they just stand and you somehow get hitted once or twice. (FIXED)Me and my friends are enjoying this game so much because its fun and open world and exploring so much new things.And in every update this game gets better and better.If you love forest and exploring on adventure to find and built stuff, you should get this game right now :DKeep it up developers, you did an amazing job on this game.EDIT: So after 500 hours I have made the most amazing bases, my friends who played it, gived up at 60 hours ingame but I continued and I will until I can. The new updates since this review came were awesome and they fixed a lot of bugs. And the canninbals are getting smarter by each update :)

number of helpful: 22 of 27 people (81%) found this review helpful30 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I came back to The Forest after leaving it alone for some time and was extremely happily surprised to see how much it's been updated. I thought to myself, "This is going to be great! I loved this game when it first came out, and now, I'm going to love it more!", I was right in thinking that, but there is a darker side to this tale.At first, everything was smooth. I did my usual method of surviving by first off, looting everything I could from the crashed plane and the luggage around it. Then I did some recon, working out if there were any cannibal camps nearby and locating a good spot for my own camp site. I found a good spot, near the beach so there was fish nearby and also the abandoned boat. I was lucky that I came across some rope so soon, so I set up some molotov tripwires around my camp, built a fire pit and a sleeping point.All was good, I was avoiding the cannibals just fine. I was spotting them off in the distance every now and then while I was hunting for food, but they never seemed to come too close to my camp. At least, until one day.I was skimming along the beach, killing lizards for their skin and meat, and as I made my way back to my camp, I heard a blood chilling god awful screech. imagine a pig cross bred with a cat that had just been stabbed by a blade covered in lemon juice, that's the kind of scream it was. Saying it made me jump would be an extremely light way to put it!And of course, I soon found what made the scream. Near my camp, sitting on a rock and just studying my home was a cannibal scout leader. I could tell since he was decorated with arms galore! At this point, a staring contest began. We both just watched each other, and I can't lie, I was terrified that he was going to attack. But then I realized something! He was alone. I made sure, looking around carefully to see if there was any others. There wasn't, so I made the first move! I struck him, whacking him with my hand made axe until he was lying on the ground in agony, breathing heavily. Then, I took out a rock, stood over him and cracked his skull in until he was dead.Doing this, I did feel a bit sick since I had just caved in a living things face with a rock, but I was safe. He hadn't alerted other cannibals to my campsite, so I felt relaxed at least. In case this happened again though, I cut up the cannibals body, taking his head and sticking it on a spike as a warning to any others that may come across my camp. I figured that should ward them off if any come too close again.I think I made a huge mistake... That night, I was sleeping, my characters sanity having gone down a little from when I cut up that corpse. But as I rested, expecting to wake up the following morning, I was stunned to find myself waking up inthe middle of the night. "What the... Why isn't the sun up?!" is what I first said. And then I remembered.You can't sleep if there's an enemy nearby...When I realized this, I dropped a brick in my underwear... The first thing I did was crouch, staying in some bushes right near my bed, looking around constantly. What was worse, the only light was the moon, since lighting a fire at night is one BAD idea if there's something nearby. I knew I couldn't do anything to draw attention, and I knew something was out there.I was constantly looking around, hearing twigs snapping, bushes rustling, things moving all around my camp, all the time I was just constantly whispering, "What the fu*k?!" over and over. Every now and then, I could see a glance of something moving around the trees. My blood pressure must of been crazy high at this point, but it was about to get a lot higher...Out of no where, like something from a nightmare, another monstrous scream rang out! It was so sudden and so terrifying that I actually screamed myself. Not like a man, either. I screamed like a little girl and yanked my headphones off, shaking my head going "No, no, no, no, nope, nope, nope, nope!" I closed my eyes, breathing and panting heavily, my hands were shaking on my keyboard and mouse...Whatever kind of cannibal was out there, it was close. That I knew. And the worst part was, I couldn't sleep until it was gone. So... I put my headphones back on, determined to be as brave as I could and I statyed where I was, hidden in some bushes, shaking like a nervous wreck as I looked around constantly in a panicked state. You have no idea how terrifying it is to have no light, everything around you completely darkened, making it so hard to see any little thing, and all the time, you hear things moving around you and you have no idea if it was a raccoon or something that could kill you...I don't know how long it took, but when the sun finally came up, I breathed a sigh of relief and gave thanks to the gods as my panting finally stopped. I was covered in sweat! Still shaking! And I looked around my camp, making whatever was out there in the night was gone. It was, so I saved my game and quit to windows until I'm next feeling brave enough to venture into The Forest.As a man in my 20's and a huge fan of horror, having loved the genre for over 10 years, I'm used to all sorts of things and this isn't a boast when I say this, but I am extremely hard to scare.However, this game, The Forest? It's the first thing in years to make me sream like a little girl. Impressive!10/10 would make my underwear brown again.And I'm so buying this game when it comes out on PS4 as well!

								Crazy fun game. I started playing 3 days ago. I was playing co-op with 2 other friends. On our 1st play through we built a pretty large base with double high stone walls surrounding our buildings and a pond on top of a cliff near the sea. content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								i3-4150, EVGA 750ti Superclocked mini ITX system. Resolution: 1920x1080Average framerate:40-60fps Max settings (Bloom off), 50-60+FPS Medium settings.Graphics settings: High-Max SettingsAverage framerate: 50-60FPSInput device used: Mouse and Keyboard.**Note** Put Terrain setting on High(Parallax Occlusion) even if you're running at low or medium settings. The terrain looks much, much more realistic while barely affecting performance and framerate. I bought this game last year and recently started playing it again. I actually just bought a copy for my brother so that we could play coop. Let me just start by saying that this is a mixed review, though I will be giving it a thumbs up because it's improved tremendously since last May. Pros: -The Cannibal AI seem to be much more intelligent and unpredictable than the last time I played. They chase you on all fours very quickly, seem to get used to burning effigies, and always seem to thwarth your plans at remaining safe.-There seems to be a few more animals and the crafting system is a little more polished.-The graphics and graphical options and presets are much more diverse. -The addition of co-op is amazing. Though it definitely needs more work, after playing for a few hours with my brother we came to the conclusion that the devs must put more focus on this aspect of the game. What I'd like to see in coop gameplay:-Sharing and giving items between players.-When hosting a game, the player I invited always spawns back to the plane after they die. I load at my last save point, see player 2 flash quickly, and they then reappear at the plane. -When a player puts meat on the drying rack, I don't see it. He doesn't see my meat. There is also a bug when we both make a log sleigh or carry cannibal bodies: They are invisible. -A bunkbed system in which the two players fall asleep at the same time. The lack of sleep in co-op is sort of unrealistic. I'd say maybe have it so that each player has to press a key within 5 seconds so that they can all fall asleep simultaneously and wake up at the same time.-When I host a game, I see a wild boar, but the other player sees a deer. This doesn't break the game, but it's quite a funny bug.-Knives. It's almost weird that they're not included in the game. They could be used to improve and/or upgrade tools and also as a weapon.-We aren't 100% certain of this, but we're pretty sure the cannibal/mutants seem to be less frequent and perhaps "dumbed down" in coop? - Rechargeable Crank flashlight?I am aware that the game is still in Early Access, but I will mention this: The developers are listening to the community and are actively working on the game. They have a very detailed list of their fixes on their website and I will say with confidence that this is probably the best early access title I've played, especially for the price that it's selling for.

content:
Posted: January 20
Early Access Review
								This game is the survival game I wanted for so long. I've played unturned and H1Z1 and rust... but none of them come close to this game. When it comes to survival games, I am not a fan of the "everyone is my enemy" mindset that people have in rust. I understand that not everyone will be friendly.... but not everyone should be toxic either. I simply could not get immersed into the aforementioned games. Now the forest, oh man. It's you (and your friends if you wish) against some scary AI. You'll always be checking your back and sometimes you'll be glad you did. The gameplay is simply fantastic.The graphics of this game are pretty outstanding as well. Everything looks nice and is realistic enough to make you feel like you're in the game. The weather is what really helps this though. There is a day/night cycle, and it can randomly rain with a storm. You'll just really appreciate the graphics and audio of this game. Overall, I have no complaints at all. There will be a bug here and there (mainly in coop) but nothing that make me want to uninstall the game. I would say this EA game has been done right and I would've happily paid more that $10 for it. Def worth buying if you want a survival game that doesn't include a community of toxic players.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off there may be two reasons for you not to buy this game right now. The first one being it's Alpha and has PLENTY of bugs which can really ruin the immersion and excitement you get during your first playthrough and in my opinion that's a pretty big deal considering this game has every element it needs to be the best (Horror) Survival game of the year. Secondly you MUST have a good computer to run this game or it will be 15 dollars down the drain, If you can't run Rust then forget about getting this game as of now and start investing in one that can run this future Masterpiece of a game.When I first started playing this game I felt a rush of excitement and fear as I did when I played Minecraft for the first time, (These games are very different but have a similiar concept, to survive and craft) This game is intense already to say the least, but again the fact it's in Alpha and has many bugs can ruin that. If you want the best experience for this game when you first play I suggest waiting a few weeksIf you want to help support the developers of this and be a part of the games journey to it's finished product then buy this, you won't regret it.Gotta give this game a 8/10Things to keep in mind when you're actually playing this:1. Use the Axe to break open suitcases, good loot and food in there2. Take advantage of the stealth mechanic and listen for the noises Cannibals make, you'll probably know it when you hear it3. If you are killed by cannibals and taken to their cave, YOU MUST get the flare gun inside the room you wake up in, don't leave it without it because you'll most likely need it to escape and it has plenty of ammo4. And above all, have funHappy hunting

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								After the massive sellout directionless flop that was Minecraft survival mode, which spawned an uncountable number of voxel survival clones, came the wave of zombie survival games of which there was an equal number with a disappointing lack of variety. The survival genre needed something fresh. Something that was survival, without the endless additions of survival mechanics, but with enough elements remaining that the game remained fun and challenging. Something that had the wonder and danger of exploration, with the terror of creatures in the night, without taking itself too seriously or not seriously at all. And something without zombies, but something that could instill just as many fears and nightmares if not more.Enter: The ForestIt's worth noting that The Forest was the first game on Steam to really start the "stranded survival" genre,  and there are many games out there currently "inspired" by its formula including Stranded Deep, Salt, Savage Lands, Better Late Than Dead, and more.All alround, this is a fun early-access game that is worth putting down dollars on.Granted I still run into the occassional bug, but that is the nature of early access. What is good about this early access game though is that the developer is EXTREMELY active with making bug fixes along with adding new improvements, they are constantly listening and interacting with suggestions and feedback from the community, and most important of all is that they are taking whatever time is necessary to make sure this game is well crafted before they try to push it forward into further stages of release. The care and quality really shows, and I really look forward to seeing its continued progress.That was all just a review of the game as it stands in the market of games however, so let me touch on the actual playing of the game.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------It's a lot of fun, and has a very different feel compared to a lot of survival games. As a gamer who is also getting older and has more and more responsibilities in life, I find that the mechanics of the gameplay also balance really well with what time I can lend to play it. That is, it has numerous survival elements which keep the game interesting and challenging, while not requiring anything you could call grinding. The atmosphere and environment of this game is really well crafted too, and the effects of lights and shadows really add a lot to the experience, I especially like the feature that your characters eyes need time to adjust to different intensities (or absence) of light to see well.The cannibals you survive amongst in the game also offer a good challenge, and a serious change of pace from most other survival games where you practically end up being invincible against ridiculous odds. In this game fighting one on one requires focus, and getting outnumbered in a fight can quickly lead to a scenario where your best option is to RUN. The cannibals aren't the only threat though, as every day you will need to come up with a way to get food, fresh water, stay warm from cold nights and rainstorms, and watch out for dangerous animals. As you start getting into the rhythm of things you begin building up your goods, and can start taking the fight to the natives. Let them know you're not to be trifled with by butchering the limbs from a fallen foe, and skewering them on a burning stake as a warning to the rest. Some times this will backfire though and the cannibals will return with a raiding party to wreck your camp, forcing you to flee from everything you worked so hard for unless you can fight well enough to defend it. If you want to return the favor, you can venture deep into the caves where the cannibals live and discover why they are harvesting all the bodies from the plane wreckage...DUN DUN DUNNNNNNNNCo-op is also great because you can use your friends as cannibal bait! :DI'm hoping in the near future the dev. will have a deliberate FFA/PVP mode, where players can paint themselves to group up in rival tribes, and to native on one another.This game is already fantastic, and it's only going to keep getting better.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been really interested in the open-world survival genre, and purchased a few of the popular early release games. I tried a lot of the ones that focus on MMO-type gameplay, and quicky became bored with them. I can only walk around for so long starving to simply get shot by some guy with a cowboy hat as soon as he sees me.I finally decided to try out the The Forest, and it's the first one of the genre that I've been thoroughly impressed by. With an indie team of 3 devs, the game has a surprisingly polished look and feel. It creates the creepy atmosphere it's going for perfectly. I'm writing this review after my first night of playing, and I've only played co-op so far, so I can strongly recommend playing with a friend (but I'm sure playing alone would be just as satisfying and probably more creepy).I already have come to love the building system. Rather than punching trees endlessly, you design out your building initially and it shows you what resources you need to collect to complete the structure. You then go out to find those resources. It's amazing how much more immersive the game is when the tree actually falls and you carry a few logs back at a time to your shelter-in-progress.Had a great time after my first few hours, and I can't wait to get a little more confident to explore the more dangerous parts of the forest.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Do you like the smell of fresh pine, sawdust, and decay on the wind?Do you enjoy chopping people down as much as you do chopping trees down?Do you love dark, claustrophobic caves full of wretched abominations?Have you ever wanted to say '♥♥♥♥ you' to Mother Earth and exterminate wildlife in several miles' radius?Then I have the game for YOU!Put short and sweet, The Forest is a Near-AAA title trapped by slow development and plentiful bugs.Even with its problems, this game has to be commended for its attention to detail and somewhat unique take on the survival genre- And even if you disagree there, it's still fun to cut trees down and build♥♥♥♥♥♥Cons:-Somewhat Cliche' storyline so far but fair enough on its own.-Could really use memory leak patching.-Needs more ranged weapon variety and customization.-Plenty of bugs.-Gets somewhat stale due to slow updates, could really use a bit of revamping to give it more replay valuePros:+Rich environment full of life, forest feels 'alive'+Pretty good graphics, especially for an "indie" title+Fairly well-done enemies that genuinely creep you out sometimes, constantly watching unseen..+Makes you feel like a true lumberjack+Lots of fun in multiplayer, many goofs to be had

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Day 1: I've crashed on some godforsaken island. Woke up covered in blood, brink of starvation and barely alive. I made it to my feet and looted the plane for goods. Nothing much, couple meals and some soda. Even found some booze which I've kept for later. Staggered outside to the site of a picturesque forest full of wildlife. I borrowed an axe from a stewardess who didn't look like she'd be needing it, and started hacking open some luggage. Didn't find much, some cloth and some granola bars. I headed out and ended up at a coast, which I followed for a while. Found some cargo containers with some circuit boards and a bunch of asprin. I took it all. Went further down and found a crashed Yacht, so I'm thinking this is somewhere in the ♥♥♥♥in' Bermuda triangle. Found some flares on that, and some rope. Headed inland but got lost, ended up at some small village with triangular buildings. Lots of dead people...some I recognized from my flight. Found a better axe buried in a tree, and more soda than I'll ever need in my life, as well as some dynamite. Headed in I think a northerly direction, found another village. Managed to kill a couple rabbits and lizards, made a small pouch for berries and glued some leaves onto the lizard skin and wore it for camo. I literally ran into some savage on accident. It ran away, laughing. Shaken, I kept heading down the hill and found some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who looked like someone had run a sword through him. I took it. Katana, very nice. Kept heading that direction and found a small pond with a tent next to it. Found a cooking pot and a spear. It was getting dark and I was hungry and thirsty, so I quickly made a small shelter out of sticks and leaves as well as a tiny fire, got some water out of the pond and boiled it, drank that and cooked my rabbits. Put out the fire and slept through the night.Day 2: Woke up early and got out of there. Walked for a long time and got lost a bunch. Ran into another savage. He rushed me, so I sliced him with the katana, but the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ was just a diversion as two more jumped me from behind. I managed to take all three down but I was hurting pretty bad, so I took some asprin and that cleared it up. Kept going and ended up back at the guy who'd been run through. Noticed there was a cave behind him, so I started going through it. I haven't been using my lighter at all, even though I explored about half of last night. Hard as hell to see but I didn't want to attract any attention. In the cave, I only used my lighter when I couldn't tell where I was going, or to check for side passages. I found a fork in the road and went left, and found another fork. Went left again and found four human heads on the ground, still decaying. Past that was some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a Bible and a crucifix in his hand. Head looked to have been eaten off, possibly while he was still alive. Dead end past that. Headed back and was greeted with a wooden wall, with a skull hanging over it, a candle in each eye. Unnerved, I cut down the wall and found another one. Cut that one down and there was a massive open chasm past that. I heard some very loud footsteps, like a giant was walking around. To my left I saw two...things. The light was bad, but they looked like two massive pillars of flesh with about ten arms apiece. Keeping in my scream was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. I scrambled past them and found a climbing rope, and descended. It was very wet down here, and I was doing my best not to slip and drown. Kept going and there was another, even bigger chasm. I took one step inside and the most terrifying sound I've ever heard in my life pierced my ears. It sounded like babies crying, but it was too high pitched, too...alien. I stumbled inside and saw big tents in one corner, which was where the crying was coming from. I crouched down and went over, and sure enough there were deformed babies twitching and crying on the rock floor, a humanoid standing over them, hunched, apparently asleep. Surrounding them in a ring were big rocks, one of which I was hiding behind, and on those wooden crates. I cut one open but nothing was inside. I quickly moved away, but to my horror the babies lunged at me. I cut them down, whimpering, trying not to make any noise to awake anything in here. I ran as fast as I could away from them, flicking my lighter on to guide the way. I went down a passage that ended in a rope. I quickly grabbed on and climbed up, hoping this was the exit. It ended much too soon, and I pulled myself up and sprinted down the passage. To my utter terror, it ENDED. There was nothing, just a blank wall and a skull with a candle in it. I slowly turned back, towards the sounds of piercing baby cries and the wind passing through the damp, cold cave. I sank to the ground in defeat, and await death.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								There are a lot of developers out there who intentionally keep their games in what I like to call 'development limbo' and add one update every so often because they make more money by doing so (Yandere Dev is a fine example). However, the developers of the Forest aren't like that. They listen to feedback and continuously fix bugs and add whole new areas to explore in their updates. These developers truly care about their audience. I've spent many hours in the game messing around with my friends and we've had so much fun. If you're considering playing this alone, I'd personally not recommend it because it takes too long to do anything. However, playing with your friends is a blast. We all love playing this game and look forward to the updates. If the developers are reading this - thanks for your hard work!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Forest is one of the many survival games you will find in early access. But in my opinion this is not one of the terrible ones. It has constant updates making the game better all the time, for example co-op just came out! But this is not only a survival game, it’s also horror. When you explore them caves for the first time with your little lighter that keeps going off you will be scared. Really scared.  Enemies The enemies are not zombies. Yes, you heard a survival game with NO zombies! This has mutants. The mutants are very well made and will take different approaches towards you, for example one mutant on its own tends to run off. It will then come back with its friends. They also attack in turns a lot. One will attack then pull back and another will try to hit you. They climb trees to ambush you and will also try to flank you. In the deepest caves you will find the really terrifying ones. These ones are proper mutants. SurvivalYou will need to eat, drink, keep your energy up, keep your health up and build a shelter. You will also be defending yourself against mutants while doing all of that. To survive you need to hunt, fish, scavenge camps, chop trees and fight.  You will need to hunt and fish to eat and keep your energy and health up. You will need to scavenge camps for items you can craft and also for food. You will need to chop trees to build a shelter, create traps, and more. You will need to fight so you don’t die. EnvironmentThe environment is amazing! From the forest its self with the high trees to the sandy beaches scattered with camps.  No matter where you are, you won’t feel safe. You will need to use the environment to help you survive.  The forest has the trees you need for the camp. Around the beaches you will find more rocks. In the caves you will find better equipment. Just remember the caves are home to the mutants. Co-op!I’ve played co-op with one friend, and in my opinion it made the game much better. It does make the game easier but it feels much better knowing you have a friend watching your back while you make a shelter. Right now co-op is full of bugs but I’m sure they will disappear one by one as the developers improve the game. I hope you enjoyed reading this review as I did enjoy writing it!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								It is worth noting that I have been highly anticipating the release of 'The Forest' alpha since the release of the initial trailer.Having played the game for a short period of time, I can already tell just how well the team has married the immersion and fun-factor. The game is pretty damned terrifying already. One minute, I'm spearing fish in a crystal clear pond without a care in the world and next I hear an array of strange animal sounds. As the rain begins to fall, I direct my attention to the source of the noise and spot a patrolling party of around 10 tribal figures in the distance. However they seem unaware of my presence and march away into the overgrowth. Around a minute later, after I begin picking up essentials from the corpses strewn around a camp located right next to my own, the cannibals burst out of the foliage ahead of me, chasing me down, surrounding me and eventually killing me.It's worth noting that the AI and animations in this game are significantly better than I expected they would be. One of the cannibals darted ahead of me from the side, abruptly skidding to a halt and preventing my escape while another realistically hopped from tree bark to tree bark above.In regards to the crafting and resource gathering, I haven't experimented too much but it seems fairly straightforward and that's not a bad thing at all. Approaching and hacking down a small plant will provide you with branches and leaves and hacking down an entire tree will provide you with logs to carry which you can store in a log holder if you've crafted one. Creating a fire and shelter are essential and the fact that you have to apply leaves to the fire to keep it going adds to the realism. Overall, the crafting is fairly immersive and skinning an animal and then picking the meat up and directly applying it to the fire all seem pretty damned seamless.The lighting seems quite advanced as well and the cavern segments remind me of the film, 'The Descent' in a good way, with the ambient sounds of water drops, stalactites, stalagmites, water reflections and numerous crystal groups. All this being said, the game is in early alpha state and there are quite a few bugs which is to be expected during this stage, wherein the player can clip through certain objects and swapping equipped items can sometimes result in weird overlapping objects but overall, I believe that this game is easily worth the price tag and I eagerly look forward to the development in the future.

To The Forest,You've grown so much...I was there for you when you called everything rocks...I was there for you when you gave me no head (which put a dent in our relationship..),When there were only 2 seats instead of 3 on the airplane.You've changed, and I like it a lot. Some things I love, Like how you now have a calm mode (type veganmode in the main menu), How you never leave me without head, how you can finally name things correctly and even added new things like deer, turtles, racoons, tree houses, traps, and so much more! I love how gorgeous you are. Your graphics make me groan. I love how you now let me invite friends and we all play with you. I also like how you now have kick...butt music that pumps me for killing the natives even though they completely destroy my a$$ in...2 or 3 hits. You do have some things i'd like for you to change. The sharks are to b*tchy.We should be able to kill the b*stards. There's hoards of birds that swarm when I create fire (Maybe it's just because it's so hot.). I dont like the naked people that visit me at 3am and stare whilst making subtle groans and gurgles. OkaymaybeIlikeitalittle... Anyway, I'm proud of how much you've matured, and how much you're continuing to grow! Keep perfecting yourself and stay beautiful!-Love, Me-

Early Access Review
								You wake up and just try to survive in a forest infested with cannibals. It's challenging as you have to worry about your health/hunger/thirst, make a place to sleep in to save the game, also make sure you're safe from cannibals as they are hard to kill on your own and they can be in packs. There are minor bugs in the game but that's to be expected since its in early access right now.The fluid co-op gameplay makes for some of the most hilarious and scariest moments that my friends have ever had together (there are not many survival horror with  games you can play with your friend). The world is huge and beautiful, a lot of crafting options, many ways to survive - I'm really surprised that this game was made by a small studio.. A unique experience, I highly recommend. Posted: December 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Recommendation based strictly on the fact that the developer has a pre-release game with a countdown timer to the next major update that has yet to see the ball be dropped on.Content updates have been steady, and it's come a long way from the glitch fest the early alphas were. Still has longer to go until all the content in, but this is one of the three foremost examples of a good pre-release program I can think of (others being Minecraft and Don't Starve).I'm not going to go on about the gameplay - standard survival stuff, but first person. A lot of fun, in my opinion, though I kind of like the zen experience of staying on the overworld and avoiding cannibals while I live a quiet version of Castaway. Has a lot of promise, and a lot of current content if you enjoy building and hunting and general survival stuff.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Forest is a great start out survival horror game. Stuck on an island with crazed cannibals hunting you down, you must survive in the primitive sense. Kill or be killed. The developers have thought about this quite well, ensuring tension but also allowing the player enough time to source survival stuff (wood for fires, fish for food, etc) to create their own journey. I have thoroughly enjoyed playing it so far, and though it is limited due to it's early access nature, I certainly think this game has large potential. Crafting items, buidling your own safe-haven and fighting to the death the creatures that lurk on the island is by far a true survival experience. This game reminds me very much of "Lord of the Flies" book, which is not a bad thing. Obviously being an Alpha version of a game, it is going to have errors, problems and long load times, but that is what you expect. The graphics is well done, especially the weather pattern and day/night system. A day feels like a day and a night feels like a night. They are long, drawn out experiences, giving the player the true sense of being stranded on this island. I cannot wait for them to make this game complete and there is talk of co-op, which would add a new layer to the game. I dare you to go and explore the dark caves and find out the truth beneath this beautiful island world. It is not 100% polished, nor is it a popular 'genre' of gaming, but to me, this is a fun, sometimes challenging and most importantly a real experience. No flash graphics, no big story lines, just a basic concept of SURVIVE or DIE. I will give this a 4 out of 5 Beers. Cheers - Frost

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review, 04/19/2015I do not by any means consider myself an expert on The forest, but so far my experience has been a blast! I have played this game multiplayer with my brother, cousin, and a few friends, and have (somewhat scantily) Followed the development of the game. The Ambience is skillfully done, the artwork looks amazing, and the gameplay, while still being in early access, is still enjoyable. I have been dinking around in this game off and on for the past few months, and have seen a HUGE improvement in the entire system, with the addition of new recipes, new mobs, new entities, better systems, etc... I know that a lot of Early Access games have turned out to be huge disappointments, but so far, this game has been meeting, if not exceeding Expectations. Developers, you should be proud of yourselves, for the progress you have been making, and while I don't know how much that means to you, I'd like to think that it means a lot coming from me. This game will probably turn out to be something absolutely amazing, and I think that the developers have a great game going on. I definately reccomend this game, and do not regret buying it while it is still in Early Access.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is an early access review based on version 0.08. I'll keep updating this post once new versions are released.Pros:--- Great concept! It is really nice to see where this is going and to have a settlement with many buildings / objects is just great. As there are no objectives we are free to do whatever we wish to do. The game requires some getting used to but I like where this is going. --- The forest itself looks gorgeous thanks to the Unity engine. The tribesmen show some great A.I. - most notable for me so far was when one of them was just injured and his friend took him away before I could perform a coup de grace. At this point this is overshadowed by the strange behaviour they show from time to time but the direction they are going is commendable.--- Lots of things to build and to craft. And the number will (hopefully) increase greatly as the DIY / Survival guide the player utilises has a lot of empty / blurry pages.Cons:--- Some only noticeable once you reload the game. Either some or all the already chopped up trees simply reappear. Also, I do not mind being able to find a huge quantity of sticks and rocks but they spawn at my settlement regularly. This  is an issue in the sense that it makes gameplay much easier.--- Some objects are floating a bit and placement of walls can be difficult at times. I "installed" a wall with door and due to the surface not entirely being flat the door glitched out and started moving constantly. --- Building rafts is not possible? I crafted one and it shot me into the air. The view was great and I survived the landing but the raft disappeared afterwards. It was pretty annoying.--- Still lots of things to complete. There are a lot of animals - deer, raccoons, turtles - but beside killing them the player cannot really do anything else.--- Clipping is possible close to cliffs / hills. I can easily get under some huge rocks that surround my settlement to access it more easily. They are, however, meant to completely protect me from one side.--- While the AI can show progress there are some strange behaviour patterns I have yet to understand. Overall, The Forest is a great survival game and I look forward to the new updates. I really want to see this in its entirety. While not having any specific objectives / quests I want to see the option to save the protagonist's child and it would be nice to receive some guidelines from time to time as to where you are supposed to go to find some good stuff. For instance, a map could be useful.

number of helpful: 14 of 17 people (82%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								My personal thoughts on this extraordinary indie game:As the lone survivor of a passenger jet crash, you find yourself in a mysterious forest battling to stay alive against a society of cannibalistic mutants. Build, explore, survive in this terrifying first person survival horror simulator.Welcome to The Island. A Indie survival-horror game, and a pretty one too! You will find yourself easily immersed in The Forest's world, a world crafted with much care and dedication. Animations are greatly done, while the simple act of chopping down a tree can be a fun experience, since visuals are splendid in this game. But this isn't everything this game has to offer, we have a pretty big island full with stuff to see, from cannibal camps, tortured survivor, abandoned camps and caves. Gameplay wise we have a few factors and mechanics, you need to gather,hunt for food, build a shelter, build fire places to light up during the night, hide indoors when it rains and many, many others. The cannibals are nicely designed, and you will find yourself interested in their background since they aren't your standard "zombies" unlike the other thousand of games with the same setting. The crafting part of the game is still basic, limited at the moment to crafting molotovs, small hunting cabins or large cabins, a small raft, a few traps and some more stuff. I will update the review once new features will be added to the game, so far I give it a personal rating of 8/10, due to the AI being a bit repetitive, lack of story (other than the plane crash, nothing more is explained or introduced) and the fact that the crafting system needs a whole lot more improvement over it. Anyways, if you're into survival games, this is a must buy for you. The developers are working with mind and soul on this project, and you will not be dissapointed.

								I understand that I don't have many hours on record at the time of this writing... that's because I had played a cracked version to test it out before I made the $15 plunge to support the developers.But holy mother of god... Very rarely has a game ever made me stay up well past midnight and far into the early morning, without feeling tired in the slightest. And let me tell you, The Forest is one of those rare gems. The multiplayer aspect is phenomenal, and I highly recommend playing this with at least one other person. Not only will it help with fighting off the hordes of cannibals that just don't seem to understand that they're going to die, but there's quite a lot of laughs to be had.- CONS -Still in early-access. But I can't complain, it's an "indie" title.It's a bit buggy, but again... it's still being developed, that's too be expected.???Cannibal somehow walked right through the door of my house. ♥♥♥♥ you, cannibal.- PROS -Lots to do!Perfect lumberjack simulator.Cannibal-killer simulator.Simulator.The ambiance and sound effects really help to keep up the immersion.Like having creepy♥♥♥♥♥monstrosities hanging in the trees and watching you? Posted: June 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I enjoy this game a lot. The scenary is beautiful, and it is a well made game. There are times when I do not want to play with the cannibals so I just type in "veganmode" at the home screen and it is the same game just with the cannibals taken away. I enjoy playing on this game mode when I like to just walk around the forest and enjoy the sights and sounds, but when I want some suspense I type in "meatmode" at the title screen to change it back to the normal game mode. It is good for people that love survival games, and I highly recommend it. However, I would suggest finding the axes and weapons that are hidden throughout the map because they do make cutting trees and fighting cannibals easier. I hope everyone enjoys the game as much as I do. :)

Posted: June 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								So for a not completed game, the Forest is pretty awesome. First PlaythroughCrash land in a forest, build a fire, vainly try to feed fire, build a shelter. Shelter gets built and there's my friendly neighbor dropping by. So I do the sensible thing and hit him with an axe, he knocks me out and drags me to a cave where I'm killed by weird Octo Mutants.Second PlaythroughVainly try to build a bonfire on a small island, slowly die from hunger until nightfalls and I'm massacred by the enemy.Third Playthrough (Co-Op!)Join some random players much, much better than me in building a camp, they mainly build, I chase flaming rabbits. Daytime comes and they go into the cave, I'm at the camp until the cannibal crew arrives, where I promptly haul♥♥♥♥♥straight to the cave to meet my pro players. I am once again killed by OctoMutants. All in all, great game, good creepy atmosphere especially on singleplayer and the co-op's a nice touch. Still a but off feeling at times, especially with chopping down trees but I definitely recommend!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								a surprisingly good game... nice graphics (Unity Engine!) an outstanding smart enemy AI: the Engine will spawn more enemies and enemy types per ingame day as a bonus to the normal cannibal/mutant/tribal people enemies. --- they will not attack you when they are not starving! you can try a coexistence and stay hidden for a long time. UNTIL you begin to harvest the forest. those woods are holy for them. ressources are respawning very fast and there are a few story-secrets, hidden OP weapons and hidden settlements of those tribal people out there in a big map.Player buildings are great and can be expanded to a real Fortress. there is a pro and a contra to this game: no tutorial at all. (which makes the first run impossible!) ...but crafting is more intuitive like this. (there is a forest crafting wiki) The player has to find out most recipes by just combining and trying. This brings immersion to crafting and makes you proud of your new upgraded spear or your personally crafted bow! (if you try it without the wiki of course.)enemies are weak overall... blocking is not op and will harm the player for 10-20% of unblocked dmg. BUT the AI hits like a truck. you can take 3-4 attacks from a normal guy and it is over. GREAT! this makes combat easy but also very rewarding! (the enemy movement is really weird and will make every fight unique!) there is no endgame! there is just an atmosphere of fear and terror for lets say 20 cool hours. if you want to build your fortress in hell. this is your game. hold out forever! ...maybe give up your fortress, lay fire and flee on your boat... maybe you will find a cave and live there... just to find out it is THEIR CAVE! :) If they can get you 2 times at zero HP, they will cook and eat you half alive! you got only 2 lives. dynamite, molotovs, a bow, spears, axes, katanas, lizard-skin-underpants for armor... a crown of leaves to be the stealthed bow sniper... or just be the naked axemurderer who invades them, hanging the heads of their leaders in the middle of their settlement. BECOME THE LEGEND! paint your face with mud and await them! Pure Freedom in Unity 5 Beauty!...or hide like me every day in a different cave after you saw what they did to your friends and how powerful their magic is. 10/10 --- Naked♥♥♥♥♥♥Demons trying to eat you and your friends in multiplayer in an excellent immersive sound and graphic atmosphere while your sanity meter reaches zero and nobody out there in ours or in their world knows what the effects of this meter are!

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I like this game, but it needs some work. By buying this game you should take into consideration you're purchasing a 'Beta' version, you won't get a completed game (yet) and there will be bugs.The BasicsHaving that said I really do enjoy this game, it's difficult, but not impossible, it's challenging, but never too unfair, surely there is quite a few bugs to be polished out of the way but that's why it's in beta. The idea is simple, gather some wood, craft some better tools, survive the night. It's more difficult than it sounds though and you will be facing numerous challenges; hypothermia, hunger, fatigue and of course cannibals.The GameplayGameplay wise this game needs some fixing, there's a few bugs when chopping down trees or mashing enemies in the face with a club fashioned out of a stick and someone's skull, not all hits will register and it can become a bit frustrating. Once you've learned to deal with these little things the game is pretty polished.It's pretty easy to get a nice structure going, and it won't be long until you have yourself a nice base, just don't forget to make a fire.With the new added in co-op feature this game becomes a LOT more enjoyable, it's double the fun when you're running around with some friends collectively hacking limbs off cannibals, and I think it's a great addition to the game. In fact, just the fun you could have in the co-op is probably worth buying this game.The GraphicsThis game looks pretty, the shadow bugs present in previous versions (your character having hollowed out eyes and neck in your shadow) are now fixed and I can't really think of any way to complain about the graphics in this game, it's imply outstanding. The world feels alive and immersive.To Summarize+ Great gameplay.+ Co-Op is a blast!+ World feels immersive, with attention to detail.+ It's a challenge, but not unfair.- Minor bugs.Thank you for reading :D

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I currently have been playing this game since V 0.6. (Nearly 600 hrs invested.) This is perhaps one of the most professional programmers I have ever seen during an Alpha release, regularly updated with large updates and hot fixes. The Devs actually do read over player input and if they see it usuable in game they will implement it ( aka, now has a pause ability). A real good community of users in multiplayer. The Game: The game has some very unique and refreshing ideas for a Survival/Horror game. It has multiple game modes from no canibals to an all out fight or die. Lots of exploration space to locate what you think will be a "safe" camp location. But who are you kidding, there are no "safe" camping sites, not for long anyways. Plenty of supplies and food and water. The building system is still a bit ganky, but it is still being worked on and changed. The atmosphere is gorgeous now that they have changed over to Unity. You choose how you want to play. Do you want to live off the land or do you want to build a small camp or a huge fortress for you and your online friends to battle the canibals. It's entirely up to you to decide if you will become a canibal by eating the canibals or if you will remain human by just eating berries and mushrroms. Just remember to keep warm and drink plenty of water and always, no matter what keep plenty of food and water on hand.I strongly recommend this game to all survival and horror game fans! No stupid planned jump scares, only real jumping out of your seat scares! Well worth the simple $15.00 usd!

content:
Posted: February 7
Early Access Review
								To me,  The Forest  gets horror right.Just not so much in multiplayer. Normally I'm not a huge fan of these types of games. The kind where they throw you into a world and say, "You have just one objective... Survive!!" That's like saying, "Hey, we don't really have an end goal for you. Just muck about in the world until you're bored." This is purely subjective, but having an open world to freely romp around in without an objective isn't enjoyable for me. I need to have something I'm working toward otherwise my efforts to get a cool base, weapon, etc. seem in vain. On personal preference alone,  The Forest  would be hard for me to recommend without being structured the way that it is. The world itself doesn’t have a whole lot to do. The game is based around you venturing into different cave systems and finding specific items such as a rock climbing pick to progress. This is both good and bad. What I like about this is that it puts you in the sense of, “I just crashed on this island. What the hell do I do?” And while you know you ultimately have to find Timmy, it doesn’t hold your hand in the direction to go. Once you’ve seen it, it’s fairly easy to deduce the location that probably leads to him, but the game doesn’t help with the steps leading up to having access to that. Now the bad side to this is exactly that. There are times you’ll come across a section of cave and it will add a note to your book saying you won’t be able to continue until you find a way to overcome the obstacle that impedes you. This can lead to a frustrating amount of backtracking, remembering where you have and haven’t been, and where you should be looking next. All while balancing health, hunger, thirst, and not getting killed and losing your stuff while trying to find what to do. Again, this is stuff that is fitting for the setting of the game. If you’re some guy lost on an island with caves & cannibals, you may very well not know where to go or what to do. It kind of becomes a balance between being immersive and what is most fun for the player. Obviously, you can just look up what to do online (like my group eventually had to do for a bit), but devs can’t assume players will do this when designing their game. In terms of horror, the game relies on atmosphere over jump scares. Not to say the games doesn't have any, however, the jump scares are more situational rather than scripted. What I mean by this is that you're more likely to be scared by a screaming cannibal that snuck up on you than you are because walking through a specific doorway had something leap out via programming. The thing I found scariest was seeing the cannibals wandering around in the distance, especially when they  know you're there and are scouting your camp. While having little in terms of defences and weaponry, there's something eerie about knowing you probably wouldn't win a fight, should they engage. Hearing screams in the middle of the night (or day even) is unsettling. Pair that with the fact that you can barely see anything at night, and you're probably not going to want to venture out far. This ambiance is sort of diminished when playing with friends. If you play with the kind of people who are always laughing about something in the game (I’m guilty as well), it's a bit hard to be scared. When I first started the game, I could not really care less about saving Timmy. As someone who was playing this with a group of the aforementioned kind of friends, Timmy essentially became a running joke. But as things went on, something grew in our hearts that made us want to save our little boy. This ragtag team of dads would give anything to see our collective son smile once more and make us another awful drawing.Honestly, though: he's a plot device. There's really no way to get the player to care about Timmy without shoehorning some sort of lame introductory story in. This isn't really a complaint. I'm not asking for that, and I don't think it’s at all necessary. What I'm getting at is that there is a point to him. The game tells more of a story in its environment, clues, and subtleties opposed to trying to force poorly done character depth onto you. I don't want to spoil anything as I was lucky enough to go into the ending blind, which I think was my favourite moment in the game. I don't mean the "ending" ending, but when you get to the end of the final cave. Try and avoid spoiling it for yourself if you can. Personally, I think it's well worth it to discover on your own or with your group.Technically speaking the game is relatively smooth, but a big buggy. It's early access so this is to be expected. I don't recall any game-breaking bugs, and there weren't even any recurring issues that I can pinpoint. Generally, there may be some problems with things not working correctly, getting stuck, and rarely having enemies act weird (as in casually walking around your base without acknowledging you, not the fact that they're naked and wearing CDs). It’s kind of stuff that will gradually be worked out closer to the full release.One issue I had was the enemy difficult. Now I’m not sure if this was amped up because I was playing co-op, but the mutant enemies seemed far too tough for a game that is almost entirely based around melee. One in particular was those big chunky, chargin' fellas (Cowboys I think?). It had happened on a couple separate occasions where I would get hit and knocked down by one of those, and he would continuously stomp on me. Each stomp would re-knock me down so I was pretty much stuck like that until I died. Ranged attacks are probably a more suggestible tactic, but regardless of your approach you shouldn’t get stuck in a loop until death if you’re hit once.My other issue is more of a suggestion rather than a complaint. I feel there needs to be a greater variety of items, mostly in the mid to rare range. There were too many times when I thought I had stumbled upon something cool and it turned out to just have a boatload of circuit boards which I was already full on. Now the problem is the game physically shows the entire contents of your inventory when you have your bag open. While this is neat and helpful to see, it doesn’t really leave a lot of room for new items to be added. Consumables are the most used form of item in the game so more permanent upgrades might be cool.It should be noted that the devs are pretty frequently releasing updates. That’s always great to see in this age of games, considering the business model of many other companies. It’s also great that the entire story/main objective/whatever you want to call it can be completed in the current build, but they keep adding content to make that journey have more depth and be more enjoyable along the way. From what I can tell the devs also actively listen to bug reports and seem to have a slew of fixes with each patch. Having a countdown as to when the next patch will be released is also very admirable. Love the consistency. Like always, I didn’t expect to write this much, but I did. Summary below.TLDR;  The Forest  is an atmospheric horror survival game which can be genuinely unsettling. It has an actual ending, which is a huge plus. Multiplayer, while not nearly as creepy, is a lot of fun in its own right. The fundamentals of the game can be both immersive and/or frustrating depending on your outlook. Devs are constantly improving and adding to the game. If it looks like something you’d enjoy, I think it’d be good to pick up on a sale.I was originally going to include a video with this review, but unfortunately my hard drive failed with all the footage on it. Instead, please enjoy this video of me cutting down a tree and having it land on our house that my friend captured.


YouTube™ Video: Homewrecker 

			Views: 105		

			Is a house really a home when your loved ones are gone?

								6/5/2016:Since getting a new computer, I now get 60+ FPS on the High preset, with AA to the max. -----------RUNS AT 30-40 FPS ON MY LAPPY:CPU: AMD A10-5750mGPU: Radeon HD 8650G 768mbRAM: 8 gigs OS: Win10EDIT: Now runs at around 30-40 fps because of OC and various heating fixes.*** POSSIBLE SPOILER ALERT ***scroll to bottom for nonspoilers I love this game so far. Everything has been amazing; the graphics, audio (mood, etc), weather is really cool, and there is just so much more. When I found out that the trees fall down, I was astounded! Never have I ever played a game with physics like this.GAMEPLAY:Also, on to the gameplay, the way everything works is great. Everything has a purpose; turtle shells, deerskin, rabbit fur, and even body parts (LOL!). It's weird how one can use someone's leg to kill another person, but IT ACTUALLY WORKS!!AUDIO:The audio in "El Forest" is decent. Well, not even decent, more like superb! Like the gameplay, every noise, sound, water drip has a meaning. The night sounds really set the mood, alike the day sounds. night is spoopy, day is happy (ish) . All in all, if you like nighttime sounds and have that one app on your smartphone that puts you to sleep, then you're gonna love this.WEATHER AND CYCLES:Weather is one of those lesser used things. Now, it may be confusing to implement, but in this game it's just great. When it rains you get cold and wet and at night you get cold, at day you start to warm up. I'm not entirely sure if the thunderstorms can zap trees, but it really sets the mood when they occur.GRAPHICS:All I have to say about this is that the developers have paid a lot of attention to detail. Next time you hop into a game (or when you get the game), take a look at all the textures and scenery. THEY WILL ASTOUND YOU!Anyways, aside from the biggies, it's a great game. It's very enjoyable, and they have coop! Who doesn't like that? Now, it does have it's bugs (disappearing logs, to name one), but it's a very enjoyable experience nonetheless.I just bought this game during the sale, but that doesn't mean it's not worth the $14.99. Unlike most early access titles, the devs pay attention to what needs to be done.*** NON SPOILER SECTION ***tl;drGraphics, Audio, Gameplay, basically everything about this game is great. When you experience "El Forest," you will see the work that was put into this masterpiece.

Early Access Review
								The Forest, Has almost every red flag there is on steam there is "Early Access, Survival, Open World, and a small team (at least as far as I have read) of four people. Yet I still bought it, along with my friends, and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥we had one heck of a time. Three things that have kept me playing and playing. 1, Even thoguht it isn't last forever, the building mechanics are a favorite of mine, very customizable. 2, The survival mechanics, the need for sustainable food, water, and not being maimed by the AI (cannibls and some wildlife). and 3(my favorite), the exploration of caves and above-ground. It's just so amazing that the same game can be rewarding in finished your base, and heart pumping when your being chased my a mutant in a small cave running toward the crawl exit. It's a beautiful game that I will never abondon, I do not reccomend the single player for the very light-hearted, multiplayer succesfuly keeps, but lowers the exitment and horror. 100/10 In my book

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								First of all my plane crash lands in the middle of god knows where. Some Hippy takes the boy I acquired pre-flight and runs off with the little swine. I paid good money for that child!Next I decide I better make the most out of the experience and pick up some of the islands finest sticks and stones. I come across a small settlement of tents by the waters-edge.Hoping to avoid an invitation to one of their terrible music festivals, I scattered on and set up a small shelter and fire further down the line. However just as one might expect, the fire attracted more Hippies.They watched me in confusion for some time, obviously never having seen a person next to a fire without a guitar before. More of them arrived and began getting aggressive. They must have misplaced their marijuana, and immediately painted the blame on the outsider. Clearly simple conversation was too advanced for these dirty, naked, smelly rascals.I awoke in a cave, joined by a good deal of deceased individuals who clearly staged a mass suicide after having given up on humanity, and not enjoying the taste of their rather strange smelling brownies. Armed with my new friend, Jibbly Jabb the lighter, I made my way out of the cave and back towards my camp, which was only a short distance away.I lasted another 2 minutes back at camp before I was unfairly and unexpectedly pummelled to death by Boob-Hippy and Winkie-Doodle.Despite the natives' lack of clothing and proper etiquette, I thoroughly enjoyed my romp in this land and anxiously await my triumphant and vengeful return.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's not many games today that offer a real challenge. Even fewer that make you genuinely afraid of the enemy to the point that hearing their call ring through the air puts you on instant alert and sends you straight into fight or flight mode. The Forest does all this and more. The preset build options are excellent and can quickly allow you to build up a safe place to store weapons and supplies but the custom build options take that to a whole new level. At my current progress in my most recent save I've built a platform at the opening to the plane fueselage with a log cabin, fire pit and I am currently in the process of putting walls around it, once done I intend to build ramps up and around a tree so I can place a tree house near the top for a good vantage point. The challenge in the game is to be able to do all that while avoiding enemies, catching or finding food to eat and locating or creating safe water sources to drink. The game has an excellent feature where by typing 'veganmode' at the games main screen you can turn off the enemies, build a base, go back to the main menu and type 'meatmode' to turn the enemies back on, reloading your savegame and you can use your newly built base as a starting point to go exploring but beware, the more days you stay alive, the more difficult and aggressive the enemy become.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								It’s finally here. We’ve all been so excited about it, and it finally releases.But before you drop your hard earned money on it, know a few things. At the current time, you are unable to save. You play until you can’t play anymore, and then restart your game the next time. It doesn’t matter how far you get. Saving just doesn’t work right now. To me that is a huge part of the game considering it is a survival game, and you need to be able to save considering the expense of resources some of the crafting takes.So purchase it at your own risk. It’s a fun game so far, but once saving is fixed, and some of the bugs are sorted it will be even better.EDITS AS OF JUNE 17, 2014Saving is now here! Bugs have been reduced, and overall the game feels a bit better at performance. Also, sharks have joined the plethora of creatures you can stumble upon!

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game provides a lot of fun. I assume at some point it's going to get stale, but as of my 10 hours playing, it's a lot of fun. At first, there was a lot of horror involved. It was freaky when a cannibal spots you because you know you're probs going to lose even 1v1, but as the game goes on, you learn more, you find more, and you explore more, so the 1v1 becomes not so bad. That creepy dessonant piano chord they play everytime they spot you still puts me on my toes, but even the cave exploring has become less scary, but still very exciting. The one thing that kills some scare factor is the fact that this is PRE-alpha, so there's a lot of bugs, and some of those bugs make it a bit... tedious. I didn't buy the game at first because it was single player only, and I knew I wasn't going to be playing it long by myself, but with friends, it's a lot of fun. Combat is good, but it's not great because of the bugs. I never see my molotov cocktails light any of those nasty creatures on fire. Sometimes the guys lag out or whatever, and you'll get hit 3 times, and suddenly you need to run back to your new log cabin to pop some meds; sometimes it's also a bit awkward with the ax swinging as well, and you're kind of hoping that you hit the bad guy, rather than using any kind of skill to kill. Building to me is a lot of fun. I never played Minecraft, but my friends used to, and I'd compare it in a way to that. High graphics horror minecraft yes? The log trekking isn't the most fun, but they added a lot of stuff to help with that. Another bug would be that ones' log sled dissapears for one person, but the one person can see it, and place and pick up logs from it. THIS GAME IS A PRE-ALPHA, no one should be expecting this to be perfect by any means, but the rate that the developers are improving it is wonderful. The Day z guys have been doing that for years, and the game is still in alpha. These guys actually set a timer for when the next update gets out, and they're making progress. All in all, if you're hesitate because of the horror part, make sure you have a friend to play with, and it becomes epic. Otherwise, what's $15 stopping you from buying this masterpeice? It has a lot of bugs, but is still a ton of fun despite that.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bloody love this game and have had it since its original release back in 0.01. In this game you can take your creativity to the next level due to such the wide variety of things available within the survival book/building book. I've made multiple saves now making things from fortresses to nice cabins. Of course this game does have its flaws but this is obviously expected due to it being in early access. Heres my personal list of pros and cons of the game.Pros:Building - ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ this feature is great as this can be used for simple survival, decoration and to save you from the nasty cannibals.Combat - This has changed ALOT over the updates but I would say the enemy AI is now considered 'intelligent' which makes the combat fair and fun.Multiplayer - I love how this has changed since its original release it's now playable and really fun to play this game with friends and family however there are cons to this.Exploration - It's really great to explore round this island with its great landmarks such as the boat, the numerous caves and the anchor.Cons:Multiplayer - There a few bad aspects to the multiplayer such as when something new that is major is released to the game it always is put onto singleplayer before they master its functionality for multiplayer.Exploration - This does lack quite a bit as fun as it is we still have to deal with such a small enviroment also there update for the extra world space was beyond disapointing due to the broken caves and barely any new cool structures which include missing colliders in the mountain.I hope this review helps you decide whether to purchase this game but ultimately I... RECOMMEND this game.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Having played several other similar games (Stranded Deep, Subnautica, Rising World, ARK, Life is Feudal, Long Dark, and of course Minecraft), I'm a sucker for this genre.I saw this game about a year ago and was tempted then, but it seemed too early. Moreover, all the screenshots made it seem like this would be a very dark (literally no sunshine) game. I just recently got it, and I'm very impressed and first want to say this game is not just a night-time scary game like the pictures & intro movie suggest. Sure, it has all that, but it also has a whole world of daylight, sunshine, and good visibility.Gameplay is beautiful and smooth for me, with lots to explore and a good deal of customization available in terms of building your base. As I mentioned, I've played several similar titles where you build a base, and I think The Forest does a really good job in terms of allowing you to place custom shapes, as well as place blueprints to visualize things before actually building. I was quite impressed by the ability to place a custom floorplan, and then automatically have walls placed around it, with the ability to toggle window/door/full wall in each section. Really well done.Multiplayer/Co-op works great, too, but could use a little refining. I haven't found a good mechanism for hosting a dedicated server, which is somewhat limiting. There's also some "instancing" issues, for lack of a better word, where some players' clients will display certain objects, like Native effigies, but other players cannot see them. This seems limited to just a couple of nuanced items. Apart from that, co-op gameplay was quite smooth; no other syncing issues or crashes (although we only have 3 people in our game).All in all, I'd highly recommend this game. Even if you're not into the Horror genre and find yourself thinking "Man, I wish Stranded Deep, Subnautica, Long Dark, etc were multiplayer"... this is a good buy.

Early Access Review
								Massive potential for this game! As of now, it is great to play by yourself as well with friends in a sort of casual manner. I think there could be variation to your character's attacks along with increasing AI tactics and difficulty. Don't get me wrong, the enemies are quite smart. They will walk on patrols alone and in teams plus they will even run away to get their friends! The scenery is beautiful and the sound effects are as frightening as they are pleasing at times (play and you'll see what I mean). If you want a little more terror, you'll find it in...dark places. The creature designs and sound effects are great and I hope they introduce more. If you like survival games, I really believe you'll enjoy this one. I'd like to add that right now the community is pretty cool. I've made more friends playing this game than any other which I believe is due to the well managed AI.

Early Access Review
								Keep in mind, this game is still in early access at this point, so there are bugs that need to be worked out; However, when compared to other survival games such as Rust, The Forest, offers suspense, a storyline, and beautiful graphical landscapes, from an ocean and beach setting, to cliffs, mountains and obviously a Forest. The natives who attack you have startled me many times, which makes it a creepy and fun experience to play in the dark. There is so much potential for this game, I can't wait to see where they go with it in the future. At this stage I would still recommend it and if they continue to add content, and improve upon the bugs, this may very well be one of the go-to survival games out there.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								"As the lone survivor of a passenger jet crash, you find yourself in a mysterious forest battling to stay alive against a society of cannibalistic mutants. Build, explore, survive in this terrifying first person survival horror simulator."This description is spot on, and despite it being Early Access, it delivers on each front. The atmosphere is great, textures and animations CAN be good, and the small interactions with the wildlife are interesting. As far as I can see, the game has potential to be a contender with any and all AAA titles, AS LONG as the developers continue with this trend. In the current state of the game, it is VERY buggy, and is essentially BAREBONES. It can still provide an enjoyable experience, but DO NOT be surprised at cannibals running in reverse at you, or even trees continually falling for what seems to be an eternity. DO NOT let this dishearten you, it's simply a matter of time and effort, and it is clear they're more than willing to put in the effort. This post will be updated as soon as I can, and I'll attempt to do it after each major update to the game. (12/27/14)

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hello,first of all i want to congrats the Developers for this awesome Idea of a Survival Game.I want to name some points of personal expression and my idea of a better solution. My mainlanguage is not English,so i hope you can excuse my mistakes. I will shortly notice the main theme and a longer explanation of "WHY".1. Lower the Difficulty OR Make it adjustable.WHY: I am experienced with survival games and it took me quite some time to figure out how to survive. I can imagine that beginners might even give this game up before they've even started to enjoy it. It started with the predators which you can easily 1o1, but in a group they are superior and if you don't have better weapons than your beginner axe, you are pretty much dead. Again and Again.2. Items reset when i load my saved game.(BUG)EXPLANATION: As this is the alpha, bugs are being expected and i'm totally assure of that. However, when i loaded my saved game, all collected things in my inventory were gone. Only the leaves and the Axe from the Airplane were left. My Buildings were all there, but my whole Inventory was gone, which resulted in a fast death. ||||| This bug makes this game UNENJOYABLE from the moment it appears. This was the point where i stopped playing (which shoud be understandable if you farm hours for something from which you know, it will reset anyways after you logout) so you better fix this fast. |||||3. A Change in "Saving the Game" OR/AND the ability to pause your game while being in the Menue.WHY: Currently you can only save the game by sleeping in your shelter, however if there is some kind of an emergency or people just want to leave the game fast, make a break or something like that the only possibility would be the shelter, but what if this shelter is being camped by a Crowd of Predators which you can't fight at the moment? Then you are FORCED to stay ingame until you solve this somehow. If you could just save the game instantly by going into the Menue and even create a pause while doing so, you would make the game a lot more comfortable for all players.These are my 3 Points and i hope the Developers get to read them.Number 2 is my minor Problem since i really found my addiction to this game but in an unplayable state.Despite these rather negative Aspects which shall be fixed soon, this game provided me an uncomparable experience and i'm looking forward on playing it again once the minor bugs are gone. I recommend it.Greetings
