content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEW PATCH V.08First of alll I'm not going to fully review the game, I'm going to answer what you probably have questions about in regards to this game. If you're reading this on the store page or reviews then you're more likely to be looking for insight on whether you should buy it or not. So here we go.Do I recommend the game, yes definately it's fun and very playable. Is it buggy? No not very buggy. I would say after the last few patches it seems to be getting better annd better. It is afterall regarded as an EARLY ALPHA title, so they could put out a new patch and totally mess it up so it's unplayable. However the development team appears to be quite responsible, attentive and would likely release a hotfix ASAP. The game seems very stable, not to buggy, fun to play and enjoyable for the most part.You can build a log cabin, build other structures, traps, craft weapons. The bad guys are mostly Natives or Cannibals and are not to difficult to fight. You can hunt animals for food such as Rabbit, lizard and (Deer as of v.08) There is no storyline yet although it appears this PC Title will eventually have a very involved scripted storyline. The world is a large jungle or forest like island, it's not huge but it's big enough; dunno if they intend to make it much larger. There is no multiplayer yet and I don't know if the Development team intend to add multiplayer at a later date.Price wise, as of October 09, 2014 at the Steam store has the game listed at CA$16.99. I would recommened it at this price.

								This is a survival craft kind of game. I see a lot of potential but am unsure about the long-term point of the game. It is still in alpha and that's fine you can't expect the final product yet, but this game definately needs something to make it feel like your going somewhere in it. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is hands down the best survival game I have ever played. Hour after hour I have spent chopping wood, hunting rabits, spearing fish, and collecting mushrooms have immersed me in a world I could believe existed and has required me to push my creativity and quick thinking to the limit.I am NOT a fan of horror games, but whether or not you go into peaceful mode or not, you cannot shake the idea that you are being watched. However, that feeling goes away as you build yourself a cabin, then some walls, and a farm, some standing fires, meat racks etc, and soon well armed with my arsenal of arrows and traps I was ready to take them on. I had always adopted a live and let live aproach to surviving with these cannibals. Until they aproached my fortress, at which points all bets were off. I caught my first cannibal that evening, he hung there until I put him out of his misery with my axe. It was a thrill, The cannibals stayed out of my way but I was dying for them to come and feel my wrath. I had my getaway raft down the cliff if things went downhill. Unaware that my girlfriend had been trying to reach me for the preceding hours my phone drew me away from my new reality. Tommorow, I shall face my fears, tommorow, I shall rule the Island. Tommorow, they shall now fear me. I am the hunter, I am the builder, I am the survivor, I am the Forest

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm not sure to recommend this game since this game is still in alpha.If you like survival games,this game may disappoint you a little bit.There're too many cannibals spawned around your house every 3-5 minutes and this thing made this game become more of a hit and slash game rather than survival game.The survival thing has become just to survive from the constant cannibals attack and you barely have enough time to build a shelter,since you have to defend yourself/flee every time 3-8 cannibals attack you.You need to know that it's really hard to kill just one of the cannibals since they have a lot of HP and high amount of damage.I wrote those things on the feedback discussion page,and I really hope they read it and repair it on the next update.If they solve the cannibal problem,there're tons of reasons to buy this game.I will totally recommend it ! The game is really interesting and you'll spend a lot of time collecting resources to build your fortress,collecting foods to save for the night time,and think how you'll survive the day each morning.The game is very realistic and I don't think you'll find any other kind of this game on steam.Of course I know that there're tons of survival games in steam,but this one is different.It's not just simply collect food-water-build shelter.You really have to build the epic impenetrable fortress in order to survive the overwhelming number of cannibals hunting you everyday.You can even burn their body parts to attract them if you want to kill some cannibals.If you have finished building your fortress,you can explore the other parts of the island,and you can even build a raft and travel to other islands ! So I suggest you wait for a while until this game is finished.This is a great game with great idea of gameplay.It's just not perfect yet because it's not done.It'll become a favourite survival game in the future.

								Haven't played this game a whole lot (I played more than what it says! About 5-6 hours in offline mode), but this is my first impression:This game was a little hard for me at the beginning because those cannibal ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s were everywhere! Like literally, they wouldn't let me alone for a minute.After understanding a few tricks that you can do in this game (and that you wouldn't imagine would be possible in a game) like covering yourself in mud, I started to get the hang of it.I was building a nice, small house next to a rock, but those ♥♥♥♥ers were there to bother me every single day, so one day I decided to kill one of those ♥♥♥♥♥es and put his head, legs and arms on a pole.  From that day, ♥♥♥♥♥es never came to visit me.The next day, while I was hunting rabbits, I realized they had a big camp right next to my house -_-...I was ready to kill all sons of ♥♥♥♥♥es, but then I fell from about 10 meters and died.  I was in a cave full of bodies hanging from the ceiling and it was 3 AM, so I just ragequitted.Definitely going to do the same thing today.Oh yes, this game has a lot of bugs, but you know, it's in its alpha stage.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDITED TO UPDATEIt's been a couple of years now that I've gotten to enjoy this title, and in this time, the game has improved and added so much that it's crazy to look back and see how awesome it was even before all of the beautiful updates.  So many new features and functions have been continuously added, and graphics continue to be improved.  It's easy to see that the team working on this game LOVE their work - this game is their baby.The Forest is still phenomenal to me, and despite having logged (as of right now) 80+ hours of gameplay, there is still so much left for me to try, and plenty left to explore.  New weapons have been added (including a wicked katana) and new building features have left the options so expansive for us players that I no longer see myself getting bored of it.  You can build anything you want on this game, from small cabins, to floating boat houses, to humongous castles made mostly of rocks.  Furniture is also included, like a bed and a weapon rack.I once complained of the imbalance between ease and difficulty of the AI enemies.  They have improved greatly on this imbalance.  I still find myself dying from time to time, but it is so much easier to defend yourself now against powerful cannibals.  Fights are no longer boring because you are constantly on your toes, making sure not to take too many hits, and probably resetting traps constantly.  All structures can be torn down, even by yourself with accidental explosives or chopping a tree too close to home.  It brings much more dynamic now, as you cannot simply stow away in a walled fort and ignore the enemies as they will, within minutes, knock down holes in your defenses.It's exciting to see how great it is, knowing they are adding more every couple of weeks.  This is one early access game that I doubt anyone has regretted buying - it's been a real pleasure watching it grow.__________________________________________________________Obviously, since this game is not yet finished, I've come across some minor bugs or annoying glitches, but considering just how severely underdeveloped it still really is, I'm impressed with the quality.  The bugs have been few and far between and the only one that actually effected proper gameplay seems to have been fixed.  From my gameplay hours, the few words I can best use to describe this experience would probably be, "Zen" and "Frustration," which may some like a paradoxical combination, but let me explain.This game is relaxing.  With stunning visuals, the scenery alone is enough to encourage lengthy exploration of its open world environment.  I've enjoyed running through thick forests while trying to strategize about where and how I'm going to build my base camp.  On the way, though, I can't help but stop and admire the lay of the land and the mountains in the distance.  You'll find funny-looking trees, beached sharks, beautiful and detailed sunsets, an expansive sky of stars, and the strangest of the island decoration, the random effigies and shrines that will pop up all over the place (most of the time, around your camp, which is gonna make you squirm a bit.)  Right now, this "open-world" is currently limited, but I don't really like to use that word because limited implies something small or confining; that's not the case.  I've already spent a few hours of playtime over several different restarts, and I still haven't discovered all there is to see.  I'm kind of at the point where I enjoy exploring so much that I may start a game just for the sole task of unearthing each corner of the available map, before it's updated and expanded more.  The best part of exploration is finding all of the creepy and often gruesome landmarks of the map - leftovers of what appears to be tourists that were abruptly killed by something unexplainable.  These patches of death pop up all over the place, just like the monsters that stroll around the island looking for their next human meal.  When you come across these setups, you will be left uncomfortably eager to disappear, and fast.  You see them and look around for a brief moment, before getting the feeling of, "Oh snap, something bad went down around here, I'd better not linger."So, the scenery is great, the controls are pretty unique, the graphics are generally bad to the bone, but I do see one major flaw in this game that makes me feel it won't be a long-term relationship: the lack of action, or rather, the periods of rest inbetween cannibal encounters.  Now that I understand how the dynamics of the game works, I can much more easily track the movements of the cannibal packs.  I've learned the general distance it takes to either be seen or to stay safely hidden.  What I don't like, is how this feels to be based solely on the distance between you and the monsters, instead of, say, how Skyrim works, with having to constantly stay in cover, out of sight.  In The Forest, you could be standing in the open, they'll be walking nearby, but as long as they don't come within a relatively short range of you, they're not going to 'notice' you, and that makes things simultaneously easier and a lot more boring.  Now, there still have been times that I've taken a stroll through the thickest parts of the forest and was suddenly ambushed, and I appreciate that level of suspense and fear that is preserved with travel.  When you're in the thick foliage and trees, it makes it way harder to spot them before they spot you.  Also, the mutant packs seem to randomly deviate from a slow casual walk to a sudden sprint, making you even more cautious to keep close to camp at all times.On that note, here's where things REALLY get me snoring.  Once you've learned the essence of the game, which is to quickly establish a walled fortress with lots of fires all around you, the action starts to come by a lot less frequently and sometimes it will cease all-together.  With my perfect strategy, I have a small house built within ten minutes of starting the game, of which during this time, no cannibals have seemed to spawn yet.  It's not often that I see the monsters before I'm done building more than half of my survival necessities.  IF you DO happen to run into them before you have protection, it's upsettingly hard to defend yourself against them, which seems unfair.  They will come to you in a pack, and they will attack all at once.  Sometimes, they will one-hit-KO you.  So here's the gist of what I'm getting at: if you do it the right way, you become OP. If you slack and struggle and don't build what you need ASAP, the cannibals will be OP.  The flaw is when you get too good at what you're doing, and the cannibals no longer become a threat and literally all you're doing is camping out at the entrance of your shack, staring each other down.  I'm hoping they will pay a lot of careful attention to this in the next few updates, and  perhaps add some interesting counterattacks to their dynamics; maybe some fires to burn down some of your walls, or flinging burning stones at you?  Why not have them sneak into your camp while you sleep?What keeps me excited about this game is knowing that the possibilities are endless, and the creators can really initiate some imaginative scenarios to keep it from becoming slack.  The bugs I've come across are as follows:Trying to build something and getting stuck on the 'placement' mode, where the opaque object stays in your sight wherever you go but will not be placed no matter what you press.  Restart fixed it.Trying to click on your builds and nothing happens.  Restart fixed it.There are still objects that disappear inbetween saving and reloading a game, like the cloths you can collect.Sticks will sometimes disappear right after I cut down a small tree.Once, to escape an ambush, I fled into the ocean and just kept swimming.  The cannibals kept chase, but they weren't swimming - they were running along the floor of the ocean beneath me.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Forest was one of the first survival games to hit the market a couple years back.  It was released as a single player game, but it now has multiplayer as well; however, the multiplayer lacks some of the features that single player holds.  Though, whether playing alone or with friends, it is an over-all fun game that stands alone from the many other survival titles.  That being said, it has been in ea for a long time now, and the devs often add bugs with updates that require more time to then fix.The survival aspect of the game is a little concerning to me.  It can seem daunting at first, but once you get past the first few days and have a solid base built, it is far too easy to stock up on non-perishable foods and beverages.  The fault comes from the fact that loot re-spawns EVERY DAY...  On top of that, hunting is extremely easy and edible berries re spawn along with the loot.  You can just run up to a deer and hack it to death with an ax if you want meat.The wildlife feel like they belong in the forest with you and there is a solid variety that ranges from crocodiles to rabbits, but like I said already, they are way to easy to kill, and the game animals basically offer themselves to you.The combat is fun at first, but it lacks depth.  There are a surprisingly large amount of melee weapons, but all of them are pointless once you have found the katana.  You are able to upgrade the basic weapons in a way that no other game allows, but again, that is all a moot point once the sword has been found.  There are a number of explosives and a few ranged weapons that are powerful tools, but just like the survival aspect, they are far to easy to acquire.The crafting portion of the game is nothing new.  Though, I do like seeing how much of the forest will be cleared while creating a base.  And I can't think of any other game that you can chop up the dead enemies and either eat them, or turn them into human effigies.The strongest parts of the game are the island and the enemies.The island is large and beautiful.  There are a number of places that can be explored that range from snowy mountains to steamy swamps, even smaller islands that you must build a boat to reach.  Once you have geared up and are feeling brave, the caves are dark and spooky places to explore that hold some of the better loot, as well as some creepy mutants that you will rarely find on the surface.  I had more fun exploring with a friend in this game than in any other.  Hands down.  The openness of the island bioms allow for different play styles to be tested before deciding what works best for you.The aspect of the enemies that makes them such a joy to me is the way they respond to you.  They don't offer any innovative attacks or weaponry, but they will often stalk you when on the surface and even run away and get backup before coming back to kill you later that night.  That type of AI is rarely found in games.  I get tired of enemies that attack without any fear of death, charging at you as  if they have nothing to lose.  The sounds they make at night and the design of some of the large mutants will mess with your mind the first time around as well.Over all, its a great game to play single-player or multiplayer.  With some balancing to the difficulty, this game could shape up to a masterpiece.  In the meantime, I will recommend this game do to its unique in-game content and enjoyable game-play, even if it is a tad easy right now.  The modest price  tag is also a bonus!


The Forest 
A Screenshot of The Forest
By: Vash(88)

								First: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME unless you want to support the developers and not actually play.The game doesn't save for a lot of people including me. The AI is decent, much better than the AI in some Alpha games that have been out for a while now *cough* DayZ *cough*But even with all this, you should only buy it if you absolutely want a game where youre only buying it to help continue its development. After all this game has so much potential and I cant wait to see what it becomes.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								My first day was excellent. I looted everything from the plane crash, and grinned. My son had been taken from me, and it was time to get revenge. I jumped outside the plane, and began drinking the booze I had collected. I suddenly have an urge to bash open suitcases. Disregarding all personal items, I grab all the chocolate bars that appear in each suitcase. "Mmm, candy." I say as I shove them all into my mouth, without unwrapping any. I open my survival guide, I knew this would happen. Glad I prepared with it. I read how to create a fire, and shelter. Then I read about the berries. I smile, turning to my right. Some berries. I look at them, and they all disappear with a click of a button. I cannot wait to dine upon more of these berries. I turn my head, and without having even gone ten feet from the crash, am rushed by three people, each naked. It would appear they are all missing genitals, which was the truly horrific part. I soon slaughtered them all, and began looking into the air, asking god for support on my journey. One of them gets up, and snaps my neck, and I fall to the floor, dead.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								(WARNING THIS IS IN ALPHA) I awoke from the plane crash only to see my son being taken away from me by a mutant. I awoke again moments later and scavenged whatever i could get from the plane, and i set off reminding my self of my past life, which i only survived 1 day. My stupid self set up camp next to the plane, only to realize that the mutants come from a cave not far from the camp. i got rekd. Anyways, i set off far away from that damn plane trying to build a fire and a little shelter i found a perfect spot near the beach, i slept. I awoke at dawn and saw a patrol of 3 mutants searching for survivors, i guess no place is safe after all. I quickly crouched in the grass. Watching from a distance i saw that they have put up some sort of pole with a skull and a bottle above it, maybe to catch rain? I was right, lightning flashed and they all scattered back in the cave. I felt relieved and now knew that they were frightened by the rain as if the rain was some sort of safe haven for me to scavenge around and get some supplies. It was getting dark, i slept and awoke at dawn once again only to wake up to a horrifying shriek from a female mutant, she ran away as i knew she was going for backup i quickly ran away from camp into the woods only to restart once again.The game is really good even with the little stuff it has in it at the moment, the graphics are splendid and the animations are well done. There are ALOT of bugs with the game but that doesn't stop it from being good, and it will only get better. Snag it right now for $15 it is well worth it.(Bugs)- MAJOR fps drops while cutting trees.- mutants will not die? (Maybe i suck)- Animations while cutting trees is clunky and does not respond at times while chopping at it.- Birds floating on top of rocks.- Mutants one hit me. (like i said i suck)- Garden did nothing at all.- When cutting down small trees the branches take a while to respond to me pressing "E" to pick it up.- When i have no more room in my inventory it says "No more raw fish" even though i have no fish.- My shadow has no headAnd there's more but they will get patched and it is in alpha.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is hands down the best survival game I have ever played. Hour after hour I have spent chopping wood, hunting rabits, spearing fish, and collecting mushrooms have immersed me in a world I could believe existed and has required me to push my creativity and quick thinking to the limit.I am NOT a fan of horror games, but whether or not you go into peaceful mode or not, you cannot shake the idea that you are being watched. However, that feeling goes away as you build yourself a cabin, then some walls, and a farm, some standing fires, meat racks etc, and soon well armed with my arsenal of arrows and traps I was ready to take them on. I had always adopted a live and let live aproach to surviving with these cannibals. Until they aproached my fortress, at which points all bets were off. I caught my first cannibal that evening, he hung there until I put him out of his misery with my axe. It was a thrill, The cannibals stayed out of my way but I was dying for them to come and feel my wrath. I had my getaway raft down the cliff if things went downhill. Unaware that my girlfriend had been trying to reach me for the preceding hours my phone drew me away from my new reality. Tommorow, I shall face my fears, tommorow, I shall rule the Island. Tommorow, they shall now fear me. I am the hunter, I am the builder, I am the survivor, I am the Forest

However, the game is going to be something much better in the future. Buy to support and help make the game better, but do not buy if you want to play a finished product.

								The Forest starts out with you're character finding himself in a tough position in the middle of a spooky forest and he must craft, build, eat and fight to survive in the dangerous areas of this large open world game.The world of The Forest is very well layed out and the most enjoyable part of the game are the caves that you can explore and raid for more supplies to help you thrive.The base building in the game is quite good, but expect alot of grinding for recourses as it takes very long to collect them.The combat can be extremely frustrating at times and I found myself dying most of the time due to an unfair glitch that launches me 15 feet into the air.If it weren't for the co-op mode then I probably wouldn't have carried on with the game.Although there are alot of glitches, it is still fun and enjoyable however I do strongly recommend that you play this with a friend.

I awoke at dawn and saw a patrol of 3 mutants searching for survivors, i guess no place is safe after all. I quickly crouched in the grass. Watching from a distance i saw that they have put up some sort of pole with a skull and a bottle above it, maybe to catch rain? I was right, lightning flashed and they all scattered back in the cave. I felt relieved and now knew that they were frightened by the rain as if the rain was some sort of safe haven for me to scavenge around and get some supplies. It was getting dark, i slept and awoke at dawn once again only to wake up to a horrifying shriek from a female mutant, she ran away as i knew she was going for backup i quickly ran away from camp into the woods only to restart once again.The game is really good even with the little stuff it has in it at the moment, the graphics are splendid and the animations are well done. There are ALOT of bugs with the game but that doesn't stop it from being good, and it will only get better. Snag it right now for $15 it is well worth it.(Bugs)- MAJOR fps drops while cutting trees.- mutants will not die? (Maybe i suck)- Animations while cutting trees is clunky and does not respond at times while chopping at it.- Birds floating on top of rocks.- Mutants one hit me. (like i said i suck)- Garden did nothing at all.- When cutting down small trees the branches take a while to respond to me pressing "E" to pick it up.- When i have no more room in my inventory it says "No more raw fish" even though i have no fish.- My shadow has no headAnd there's more but they will get patched and it is in alpha.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Forest is a well developed game with both it's positives and negatives. The graphics are superb for a 870mb game and the gameplay is quick and smooth making it an enjoyable experience. However for the amount of time the game has been around it seems fairly limited in development. Yes, the producers do keep bringing out 'small' updates and generally listen to the community when it comes to little hot fixes. But the content of the game iss very limited, you are isolated to only 1 island to live off, you dont have the option to leave the island to go in search of different territory. Also there are no achievements or goals to aim for, all you have to do is, chop down trees, gather logs, ransack the respawning suitcases for never ending food and supplies, make a boat, go spelunking and your done.If there was more content in the game and a wider variety of things to craft i would rate this game 9/10, but as it stands I would give it a mere 5/10..

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm not sure to recommend this game since this game is still in alpha.If you like survival games,this game may disappoint you a little bit.There're too many cannibals spawned around your house every 3-5 minutes and this thing made this game become more of a hit and slash game rather than survival game.The survival thing has become just to survive from the constant cannibals attack and you barely have enough time to build a shelter,since you have to defend yourself/flee every time 3-8 cannibals attack you.You need to know that it's really hard to kill just one of the cannibals since they have a lot of HP and high amount of damage.I wrote those things on the feedback discussion page,and I really hope they read it and repair it on the next update.If they solve the cannibal problem,there're tons of reasons to buy this game.I will totally recommend it ! The game is really interesting and you'll spend a lot of time collecting resources to build your fortress,collecting foods to save for the night time,and think how you'll survive the day each morning.The game is very realistic and I don't think you'll find any other kind of this game on steam.Of course I know that there're tons of survival games in steam,but this one is different.It's not just simply collect food-water-build shelter.You really have to build the epic impenetrable fortress in order to survive the overwhelming number of cannibals hunting you everyday.You can even burn their body parts to attract them if you want to kill some cannibals.If you have finished building your fortress,you can explore the other parts of the island,and you can even build a raft and travel to other islands ! So I suggest you wait for a while until this game is finished.This is a great game with great idea of gameplay.It's just not perfect yet because it's not done.It'll become a favourite survival game in the future.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am obsessed with this game right now it's so fun. I have about 20 hours of gameplay and I have been having a blast crafting, building, and showing the natives that I'm not somebody to be trifled with. I'm decked out in nearly maxed out bone armor and have built myself  some defensive/offensive traps and a sturdy wall to protect my beach-side retreat. I even  have a dock, a raft, and a houseboat with a bed and decorative lighting. This game is awesome so far! Great graphics; smooth/speedy game performance; Pretty smart A.I.; item and base crafting; weather effects; and the list goes on. Coop has been very fun too and building can obviously go much more quickly. Enough, Buy it already.  Did I mention great Developers as well.I now have 287 hours of game play in The Forest and it's still my favorite coop survival/action game by far.  And of course single player is awesome and super intense in this game for certain.

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								The Forest starts out with you're character finding himself in a tough position in the middle of a spooky forest and he must craft, build, eat and fight to survive in the dangerous areas of this large open world game.The world of The Forest is very well layed out and the most enjoyable part of the game are the caves that you can explore and raid for more supplies to help you thrive.The base building in the game is quite good, but expect alot of grinding for recourses as it takes very long to collect them.The combat can be extremely frustrating at times and I found myself dying most of the time due to an unfair glitch that launches me 15 feet into the air.If it weren't for the co-op mode then I probably wouldn't have carried on with the game.Although there are alot of glitches, it is still fun and enjoyable however I do strongly recommend that you play this with a friend.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDITED TO UPDATEIt's been a couple of years now that I've gotten to enjoy this title, and in this time, the game has improved and added so much that it's crazy to look back and see how awesome it was even before all of the beautiful updates.  So many new features and functions have been continuously added, and graphics continue to be improved.  It's easy to see that the team working on this game LOVE their work - this game is their baby.The Forest is still phenomenal to me, and despite having logged (as of right now) 80+ hours of gameplay, there is still so much left for me to try, and plenty left to explore.  New weapons have been added (including a wicked katana) and new building features have left the options so expansive for us players that I no longer see myself getting bored of it.  You can build anything you want on this game, from small cabins, to floating boat houses, to humongous castles made mostly of rocks.  Furniture is also included, like a bed and a weapon rack.I once complained of the imbalance between ease and difficulty of the AI enemies.  They have improved greatly on this imbalance.  I still find myself dying from time to time, but it is so much easier to defend yourself now against powerful cannibals.  Fights are no longer boring because you are constantly on your toes, making sure not to take too many hits, and probably resetting traps constantly.  All structures can be torn down, even by yourself with accidental explosives or chopping a tree too close to home.  It brings much more dynamic now, as you cannot simply stow away in a walled fort and ignore the enemies as they will, within minutes, knock down holes in your defenses.It's exciting to see how great it is, knowing they are adding more every couple of weeks.  This is one early access game that I doubt anyone has regretted buying - it's been a real pleasure watching it grow.__________________________________________________________Obviously, since this game is not yet finished, I've come across some minor bugs or annoying glitches, but considering just how severely underdeveloped it still really is, I'm impressed with the quality.  The bugs have been few and far between and the only one that actually effected proper gameplay seems to have been fixed.  From my gameplay hours, the few words I can best use to describe this experience would probably be, "Zen" and "Frustration," which may some like a paradoxical combination, but let me explain.This game is relaxing.  With stunning visuals, the scenery alone is enough to encourage lengthy exploration of its open world environment.  I've enjoyed running through thick forests while trying to strategize about where and how I'm going to build my base camp.  On the way, though, I can't help but stop and admire the lay of the land and the mountains in the distance.  You'll find funny-looking trees, beached sharks, beautiful and detailed sunsets, an expansive sky of stars, and the strangest of the island decoration, the random effigies and shrines that will pop up all over the place (most of the time, around your camp, which is gonna make you squirm a bit.)  Right now, this "open-world" is currently limited, but I don't really like to use that word because limited implies something small or confining; that's not the case.  I've already spent a few hours of playtime over several different restarts, and I still haven't discovered all there is to see.  I'm kind of at the point where I enjoy exploring so much that I may start a game just for the sole task of unearthing each corner of the available map, before it's updated and expanded more.  The best part of exploration is finding all of the creepy and often gruesome landmarks of the map - leftovers of what appears to be tourists that were abruptly killed by something unexplainable.  These patches of death pop up all over the place, just like the monsters that stroll around the island looking for their next human meal.  When you come across these setups, you will be left uncomfortably eager to disappear, and fast.  You see them and look around for a brief moment, before getting the feeling of, "Oh snap, something bad went down around here, I'd better not linger."So, the scenery is great, the controls are pretty unique, the graphics are generally bad to the bone, but I do see one major flaw in this game that makes me feel it won't be a long-term relationship: the lack of action, or rather, the periods of rest inbetween cannibal encounters.  Now that I understand how the dynamics of the game works, I can much more easily track the movements of the cannibal packs.  I've learned the general distance it takes to either be seen or to stay safely hidden.  What I don't like, is how this feels to be based solely on the distance between you and the monsters, instead of, say, how Skyrim works, with having to constantly stay in cover, out of sight.  In The Forest, you could be standing in the open, they'll be walking nearby, but as long as they don't come within a relatively short range of you, they're not going to 'notice' you, and that makes things simultaneously easier and a lot more boring.  Now, there still have been times that I've taken a stroll through the thickest parts of the forest and was suddenly ambushed, and I appreciate that level of suspense and fear that is preserved with travel.  When you're in the thick foliage and trees, it makes it way harder to spot them before they spot you.  Also, the mutant packs seem to randomly deviate from a slow casual walk to a sudden sprint, making you even more cautious to keep close to camp at all times.On that note, here's where things REALLY get me snoring.  Once you've learned the essence of the game, which is to quickly establish a walled fortress with lots of fires all around you, the action starts to come by a lot less frequently and sometimes it will cease all-together.  With my perfect strategy, I have a small house built within ten minutes of starting the game, of which during this time, no cannibals have seemed to spawn yet.  It's not often that I see the monsters before I'm done building more than half of my survival necessities.  IF you DO happen to run into them before you have protection, it's upsettingly hard to defend yourself against them, which seems unfair.  They will come to you in a pack, and they will attack all at once.  Sometimes, they will one-hit-KO you.  So here's the gist of what I'm getting at: if you do it the right way, you become OP. If you slack and struggle and don't build what you need ASAP, the cannibals will be OP.  The flaw is when you get too good at what you're doing, and the cannibals no longer become a threat and literally all you're doing is camping out at the entrance of your shack, staring each other down.  I'm hoping they will pay a lot of careful attention to this in the next few updates, and  perhaps add some interesting counterattacks to their dynamics; maybe some fires to burn down some of your walls, or flinging burning stones at you?  Why not have them sneak into your camp while you sleep?What keeps me excited about this game is knowing that the possibilities are endless, and the creators can really initiate some imaginative scenarios to keep it from becoming slack.  The bugs I've come across are as follows:Trying to build something and getting stuck on the 'placement' mode, where the opaque object stays in your sight wherever you go but will not be placed no matter what you press.  Restart fixed it.Trying to click on your builds and nothing happens.  Restart fixed it.There are still objects that disappear inbetween saving and reloading a game, like the cloths you can collect.Sticks will sometimes disappear right after I cut down a small tree.Once, to escape an ambush, I fled into the ocean and just kept swimming.  The cannibals kept chase, but they weren't swimming - they were running along the floor of the ocean beneath me.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Summary:The Forest is an extremely incredible game for early access, and doesn't disappoint! Realistic, scary and beautiful.As one of the survivors of a mysterious plane crash on an island, you are put to the task to survive. There are cannibals, they will kill you. That is why you need to kill them. You will have to explore dark caves, cannibal camps and historical events which all makes sense in the end. All you have to do is survive and complete the game, yes there is an ending. All you have to do is to survive, survive in The Forest. ----------------------------------------------------------Holy crap this is amazing for an alpha game, even with bugs! Just wow!Looks good, feels very creepy and is extremely fun, especially with friends.I would strongly recommend this game above any other early access survival game. Sure, Rust is also good, but The Forest is a different kind of game.This game is very realistic (apart from bugs  & stuff, but you will get used to them and usually think they are funny) compared with Rust for example. Rust isn't realistic..

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Type of Game:First Person Survival HorrorVersion Played:PC version through SteamSimilar Games:Rust, DayZ, and to a lesser degree The Stomping GroundThe Good:- A refreshing take on the survival/crafting genre that emphasizes narrative more than its competitors.- The large and open world creates an exciting setting for exploration and resource gathering.- Thankfully most of the world (that I’ve seen so far) has elements that keep it interesting. While a lot of the game finds the player navigating a forest (SURPRISE!) you’ll find a number of set pieces and environments that make it worth venturing further.- The Forest is very difficult, as a survival game should be. Resources must be gathered and shelter crafted. All the while you are being observed/stalked by the island’s frightening inhabitants. Finding the right balance of finding shelter, warding off the natives, and venturing out is arduous but rewarding. It almost has a roguelike or PDL feel about it.- The Forest feels like an interactive version of the TV show Lost. As I played I experienced similar feelings of wonder and intrigue that I did with the plot of the show.- The crafting system is quite different from most crafting games I played. The player uses a Survival Book to identify items that they want to craft. Once selected, you place the outline of the object on the ground, which visually features each of the resources needed to craft the item. As you begin adding resources you can see them being added to the overall crafted item in real time. It is a small detail, but very immersive and intuitive.- Resource gathering also has a neat way about it. One example is wood: wood comes from trees that you literally have to chop down (chunks of it slowly remove as you chop) and then harvest from the fallen tree, which actually falls down with force and physics.- Resource management is handled by a backpack with limited space, which you have to manage in real time. Combining objects requires you to place them together in the middle of the satchel. I found this to be a welcome addition to immersion factor.- For the first time when playing a “survival” game, I felt like I was using actual survival techniques to stay alive. Questions that one would really ask themselves in a survival situation were constantly running through my mind: “Should I stay close to the plane wreckage and build shelter here, as there is an abundance of supplies? Do I venture further away so that I potentially steer clear of the natives? What if I find a cave that will offer the security of only having to protect one entrance?” etc.The Bad:- There a numerous graphical glitches that pop up occasionally. Just checking out the community boards on Steam will enlighten you to the extent of these glitches. Some of these are TERRIFYING!- While there is definitely plenty to see and do in the current build, the game seems to be missing more elaborate fauna and flora. It would add a lot to the already enjoyable survival experience.- As enjoyable as the plot/setting is, I feel like there should be some further incentive to explore. I wouldn’t want anything that holds my hand through the narrative, but some elusive shrines or hidden lore would be welcome.Can you play it while the children are awake?:Absolutely not. The main screen depicts a gruesome vigil that unintentionally terrified my six year old when he woke up from his nap. This game is labeled a survival horror game for a reason. Did I make time to complete it?The game doesn’t appear to have an ending, as such. At my best I survived a whopping three days on the island, which I felt was an accomplishment.Redlight or Greenlight?This game is currently at a greenlight.While a single player survival horror game may sound like it would get stagnant quickly, the intelligently designed environment and intriguing overall game design keep it from getting old. The Forest excels in areas that I never knew were lacking from other survival games: purpose, intrigue, and design. I went into it expecting another DayZ clone, but ended up enjoying something quite unique. This all from a game that isn’t even close to completion. As long as the development team doesn’t deviate from the core gameplay fundamentals, the updates to this game should end up being free DLC to early backers.This game is well worth the $14.99 asking price.A Quick Look at Those Games you Might Buyhttp://www.gamersglance.com

content:
Posted: January 25
Early Access Review
								Purchase Date: 1/23/17Initial Review: 1/25/17Craft/Building Mechanics:So far the game has been exceeding my expectations as far as crafting complexity goes. When comparing to other games of this genre, it appeared as though it was going to be to dumbed down to be of any real fun, but as it turns out, the simple nature of the crafting system is complimented and reinforced positively by the sheer flexibility of the building system. You're not constrained to build on any particular grid-line, tile or voxel. It feels much more like drawing lines in Microsoft Paint, encouraging free-form building. This is a huge plus for me. Atmosphere:A huge plus is in the environment and atmosphere. Sounds are superb, the forest undergrowth is accurate, the lighting is realistic and purposeful, and the legitimate sense of unease is deffinately there. I'm always looking around for movement to make sure I'm not getting ambushed by enemies, glacing at every dash in the shrubery only to learn it was only a deer racing through the surrounding flora. Ocean swimming is likely one of the most impressive moments actually, because of the flow of waves and swells in the ocean that are very realistic, and makes me feel as though I'm really swimming in the ocean (I'm a deep sea diver, so you can't fool me with lame ocean mechanics). Combat:The current combat system is alright, although I'll enjoy it more when the system evolves more as far as enemy tactics and siege mechanics. I've only encountered the basic enemies so far, so my frame of reference is limited, however I'm looking forward to seeing the tougher more advanced mobs further along in the game. Storyline:Despite what I read in other reviews, there actually is a storyline, and a greater mystery to unfold as you explore and scavenge your way through the surface of the landscape in addition to the depths of it's underdark. Overall:I endorse this game for those who like survival horror/sandbox genre games, and don't mind playing pre-launch style titles. This game gets regular updates and from what I've seen in the changelogs, it just keeps getting better and better. Totally worth the $15 that I paid, (bought it for my kid's steam account as well for local Co-Op capabilities). If you're complaining about the price being too much, maybe it's time to get a better job. I'll review again after a month or so of additional gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 11
Early Access Review
								I've played approximately 35 hours now in this game and I think it is well worth the money. I've never been into anything horror related, albeit this game is more of a thriller than a horror game, but what really makes the game so enjoyable is the co-op experience. Honestly, I have been watching this game for about a year and I'm glad that I waited some because earlier versions of the game looked somewhat uneventful. 0.52b is a ton of fun and I really hope this game makes it to beta/full release very soon because I would love to see more content.Pros:-Expansive crafting system that is enjoyable to learn-Surprisingly attractive graphics for a $15 game-Lore-intensive storyline, that is extremely subjective. Requires the player to figure out what happened. Different people have different theories often.-Stable multiplayer, never really experience FPS issues -Suspenseful gameplay, especially when traversing caves, with nothing but a lighter-Enemy classes, where taking out a leader first can end an enemy raidCons:-UI is difficult to use especially during combat. It makes sense for this to be the case but hot keys would be a great addition-Collisions for items, sometimes falling off the map, namely smaller objects-Collisions with moveable objects, sometimes causing you to launch into the air and lose significant health, including players-AI could use improvements, I've seen natives and animals often caught running in endless circles for no apparent reason-The building system needs to be polished. It's pretty difficult to build an attractive base at this point in the game. Maybe the devs want to keep it that way but I like to build bases with 90 degree angled walls and platforms that connect seemlessly. Right now it is very difficult to accomplish that. Overall I really enjoy this game. It has a great effect of realism. The audio is done very well and that is extremely important to me because I produce music and sometimes scores, so I tend to critique that sort of thing harshly. It's not a perfect game but I think it could become a new standard if the devs ever finish it.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								AWESOME, AWESOME, AWESOME. Open world adventure in a mysterious land. No instruction manual, but somewhat of a reference guide on the environment around you (which keeps expanding the more you discover, the guide, not the land*).  The story is very light so far; you're stranded on this unknown land due to your plane crashing, your son is taken by the natives, and you gotta make yourself boss to fend off the zombie-like people roaming around (which are mostly naked...yes, even women) *interest spark*.     It isn't a hack and slash, you must time your attacks precisely- and even though not hard, it can be very punishing (similar to Dark Souls series) were you must play smart between taking hits, healing and reacting to the enemy attacks. Practically anything and everything can be gathered and crafted into something. A decent amount of weapon choices: spears, axes, swords, explosives, exc. catapults, tree houses, water houses, bombs, booby traps, skull bombs all included  ***The best thing is that the developers are still working on it and plan on adding more awesome things. Multiplayer is pretty fun, jump into your friends' games or invite them to yours to create villages of awesomeness. Graphics are very good considering the budget on this game.well what are you waiting for mate? buy it!

PROS: - Great atmosphere to get lost in- beautiful (for an alpha)- satifying gameplay- fanastic sounds- enemies that can actually scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you when they sneekl up on you (they are also creepy as♥♥♥♥♥-very satisfying crafting and building system-NO EQUIP LOAD- totally funcional sneaking mechanics-amazing areasCONS:-loading a game dosnt save controller/ keyboard settings or graphics settings- no quick select for items (everything needs to be used directly from the items menu, even in the quick combat that the game offers)- Seemingly small above ground map (comparitively to tripple A games)- underground is VERY EASY TO GET LOST IN- items menu doesn't work as well with a controller ( the curser is very slow)-I cant seem to get the aiming reticle to ever show up.If you like to get lost in super emersive worlds and survival, then BUY THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: February 2
Early Access Review
								Welcome to my extremely serious review of "The Forest" The Forest is an early access title that definitely shows promise for its future. Development seems to be active as bug fixes and content updates are being put out quite frequently. The stability of the game isn't very polished yet, but the adventurous nature of the gameplay is what keeps me playing. Forage, fortify, hunt, explore, and... hide? ( The last one was a bit of a joke, unless you're a little scaredy cat such as myself ) Survive the onslaught of cannibalistic tribe members! These things will creepily stalk you from the very start of the game. Tensions between the player and the AI savages can increase depending on the player's actions. Will you kill them on sight? Or perhaps simply engage into some friendly political diplomacy? Nawh. Either way, the cannibals will eventually start to breathe down your neck to the point where having a sturdy fort might sound like a good idea. After that concept piledrives itself into that noggin of yours, It's time to get to work! Most of your time spent at the start of the game will most likely be building the base of your dreams. Unless you're an intelligent person that strives for optimization, you'll probably put way too much effort into building a badass fortress ( I'm implying the fact that cutting down trees is all you'll be doing if you don't think small and compact ). After you've made your sweet base, It's time to venture out into the unknown wilderness and explore! Don't mind the nudists off in the horizon that dash from tree to tree, they're simply observant individuals, that's all. Gameplay: Cutting trees / 10Story: Hm? Son is kidnapped by cannibals? I have more important matters to attend to such as spending days on end crafting and refining my masterpiece of a base.Bugs: Quite buggy but not like BUGGY buggy, you know what i'm saying?Overall: Buy it with some friends and you'll have a grand ol' time.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								An amazing survival game, where you can explore through caves or run across plains. From shooting down a deer with your bow you made out of sticks and cloth, or grab at oysters at the beautiful ocean. But be warned! Monsters crawl around, and can attack at any minute (unless you have a cheatcode activated, of course) At the blink of an eye, your life could be taken with one swipe from one of the powerful mutants. The island is contaminated with these, some angry, some passive, but never fully peaceful. An incredible game! I find that multiplayer makes it more fun, because I don't necessarily enjoy single player games for too long. Stab your pals and play tug-of-war with a human leg, you decide. Fight over which gets to cook the body, or who gets to keep the lizard skin!Despite the glitches, the game is amazing, and I really hope it keeps improving. I suggest more fur armors, like jackets and hoods that you can create out of pelts and furs. And, of course, make the cannibals less glitchy, and make them smarter. (No offense to those man-eaters, right there.)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Easily one of the best survival/sandbox games around. The crafting is straightforward yet rewarding. The hunger/thirst system isn't overdone to where it ruins the game. The combat system is fluid and satisfying. The environment is immersive due to the amazing audio and visual work.Speaking of the visuals, I have A LOT to say about this game's graphics. Not only does it have the most gorgeous visuals (compared to the likes of other early access survival games Rust, Miscreated, 7 Days to Die, etc.) but it's clear that the developers put effort into optimizing the game as much as possible, providing a smooth and frustration-free gameplay experience. I can't say the same for the other survival games I mentioned, which are all graphically inferior to The Forest, yet also run at a much lower framerate. I can really tell that a lot of time and effort was put into optimizing this game because my GPU load actually reaches 90% and above during gameplay, and I constantly get above 60 FPS on max settings on my GTX 960 4GB.  With other survival games that are terribly optimized, my GPU load will be at 50-60%, and my CPU load will be at maybe 70%, but the game still runs like trash. That's poor optimization.I have high hopes for this game, and will continue to play it and support it, recommend it to my friends, etc. Can't wait for additional content and the official release.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you wish to play a truly-gripping survival horror game still in production, and wish to give feedback and help the development of said game, then The Forest is truly for you-- if you can deal with bugs, glitches, and some unpolished spots. Despite said issues, there are several redeeming factors-- I am an avid horror fan, and many horror games have failed to deliver for me, but I can assure you that The Forest is a truly nerve wracking experience and it is quite exquisite. There are several more things the developers plan to add and are currently working on, and if you have any ideas or feedback to give to them, it is a perfect time, seeing as how it is in Early Access and still in heavy development. If you can't deal with some unpolished spots, bugs, and such, I still highly recommend the game-- Just wait a while until they flesh the game out more and polish it.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've owned the Forest nearly since it first appeared on Steam (or at least since I first spotted it and instantly bought it) and watched it grow from a scary, solo forest game with much charm to an incredible survival experience.The graphics are superb, something that few of the other games in the genre can compete with. The best thing about it is how much better it's optimized than the other early access survival games out there. You don't have to put your settings down just to be able to run the game at acceptable FPS. This is an example where devs know that adding content to a game isn't the most important thing. (Dat water though)That said, since I've started playing The Forest the content that has been added has only improved the experience. I've found with some games in the genre that they often take a few steps back with their updates, changing things that didn't need changing. So far The Forest has been building on its strengths and it's not trying to be something that it's not, nor is it copying the other survival games simply to be able to compete in this overcrowded genre.The crafting system is easy, yet has a lot to offer and be creative with. We've built everything from a tree-house town to a large compound. The traps are a nice touch too.Since the introduction of co-op and mp it's also brought a whole new perspective to the game....and it's less scary with friends around. :) I feel like The Forest is a reason to trust in Early Access games and I feel comfortable recommending it to everyone I know. Even at its current state it's a game that surpasses many of the other survival games.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok so to start, this game is constantly updating and is always looking for ways to improve. The creators of the game really care about the community too. I've posted loads of feedback/errors and most of the time, someone whos created the game or just the fan base responds quickly. If no one responds they go ahead and release a hotfix to fix the issue. The game is in alpha but who cares, buy it now and watch The Forest rise to its undoubted potential. seriously though xDThe game requires a decent pc to run, but all this will be fixed with optimization over time, so nothing to worry about there. I have a GTX 770 and an i5 3570 and have no problem running the game 60 FPS while recording. Think of this game as GTA 5 ( the open world aspect ) meets minecraft ( the survival aspect ) having a baby naming it johnny but then legally changing it to The Forest and constantly feeding it more and more updates to make it better. And there you have The Forest. I don't recommend this game, i honestly think everyone should own it. Like i said GTA meets minecraft. But in all seriousness its minecraft on steroids and some other drug taken from sweet savory squid intestines and pork tenderloin. Ok so with all that aside, you're all going to buy this game and if you dont like it, well to be honest... i dont know whats wrong with you <3

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								First run through I got my camp set up near all of unusable tents, had a fire going, and everything was alright until it began to rain. I needed sleep, so I slept and woke up in pitch-black darkness with rain still pouring down. Back to sleep, wake up and it's still dark and raining; repeat about four more times trying to find the day until I got ambushed, sent to the cave, and found the glitchy little crevice behind the dead man on the table then fell to my death under the map. I'm pretty sure I got beaten to death with a dead seagull when I was trying to build a basic shelter on the beach on my second try. When I got back, I saw a lone tribal on the beach. he tilted his head back and let out a high-pitched shriek and then  saw a group five tribals run out of the woods onto the beach; I assume the two actions were related, I hope that they were. I was terrified getting off the plane at the start not knowing how to do anything and jumping at every sound afraid of being rushed by tribesmen, it was so much fun. This game may be in development, and it may be full of bugs and glitches, but it was so worth the $15 dollars. Cannot wait to see it progress.

Early Access Review
								I'm just going to say that I understand that this is an alpha and an early access game so any negatives I may mention are simply highlights of the main problems that I think should be dealt with sooner rather than later. Its got really good mechanics, it's a very natural and beautiful looking game and has a nice cosy feel to it - it seems to flow quite nicely. It's just I can see it getting a bit repetitive and especially because the likelihood of getting anywhere is slim as the cannibals appear at my base in less than a day (and also whenever I dismember the dead cannibals they tend to explode which killed me midway through my first effigy). Aside from that though it lives up to the hype - it's scary, eerie, and also quite lonely save for the odd turtle or lizard. Also as a side note the rather safe log cabin assembles itself in mid air (not sure if it moves to the ground when finished because I haven't been able to accumulate 82 logs yet). It is a game that would be worth playing at night as it would create a great atmosphere as well as the fact that it might be easier to see things as the in-game brightness can make this quite difficutlt (logical when you're in a cave I know but it does tend to take away the inquisitive nature of the game if you have to study something meticulously up close with a very weak lighter just to see what it actually is). The cannibals themselves though I expected to sort of become more brave and dangerous as the game progressed which i'm sure is the aim in the next few patches, but at present they attack straight away and the fact that they spawned at my base on multiple occasions whilst I was out collecting logs also made it very difficult for me to progress as I couldn't then access my gear. Overall I would say that a few tweaks of the above mentioned issues would make the game worthy of a fuller release were they tackled correctly and with the few developers there are it is a momentous achievement to have produced such an immersive experience so far - I can't wait for what's to come! Keep it up :)

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								First run through I got my camp set up near all of unusable tents, had a fire going, and everything was alright until it began to rain. I needed sleep, so I slept and woke up in pitch-black darkness with rain still pouring down. Back to sleep, wake up and it's still dark and raining; repeat about four more times trying to find the day until I got ambushed, sent to the cave, and found the glitchy little crevice behind the dead man on the table then fell to my death under the map. I'm pretty sure I got beaten to death with a dead seagull when I was trying to build a basic shelter on the beach on my second try. When I got back, I saw a lone tribal on the beach. he tilted his head back and let out a high-pitched shriek and then  saw a group five tribals run out of the woods onto the beach; I assume the two actions were related, I hope that they were. I was terrified getting off the plane at the start not knowing how to do anything and jumping at every sound afraid of being rushed by tribesmen, it was so much fun. This game may be in development, and it may be full of bugs and glitches, but it was so worth the $15 dollars. Cannot wait to see it progress.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a while this game was incredibly buggy; to the point of being unplayable. To some, it may still seem this way. However, if you look at it more objectively you see that most of it isn't buggy. The only two awful bugs that they absolutely NEED to fix to make this game work is the fact that there are some world holes around ponds, and that sometimes you fall down ropes (NOTE: The rope glitch has been fixed). Otherwhise, the AI, the combat, the crafting, everything other than those two things, works marvelously. The only thing that The Forest is currently lacking in is bug fixing, and content. Two things which it SHOULD be lacking in, at this point in the game. Also the Developers are ♥♥♥♥ing great.But anyway, onto the reasons I love the game itself.The thing that really stood out to me wasn't the pretty graphics, or the creepy cannibals, or the survival aspect, it was the cannibal's AI. There are SO many things that the cannibals react and adapt to. I'll give a few examples1: The Cannibals can be somewhat reasoned with - The first few times you see the cannibals, especially if you are NEAR the plane (they see you as less hostile the closer to the plane you are) they aren't there to kill you, or even hurt you. They come to check you out, see if you're a threat, and they'll probably just leave you alone if you're not too much of a threat. For instance, as long as you make sure they are in your line of sight, you don't back up to their advances, or go towards them threateningly, they won't attack. If they run to you and attack once, block it, and then if they attack again, they will ACTUALLY mean to fight. Sometimes they just want to see if they can land a hit, and will back off after you block it. Cutting down trees, overhunting, and overbuilding also makes them more hostile. Hiding your fires from view makes them less hostile as well, as they hate fire. There are many other things that make them more/less hostile, but I myself don't know many anyway. The last, most noteable thing is that if you overhunt, and do things to bother the cannibals, and if you let survivors that spot you get away, they will send raiding parties of increasing numbers after you, until they finally get tired of you surviving them, and send the creepy, huge monsters that are in the trailer at you2: The Combat Is Realistic, and the AI isn't bad at all, especially for an Alpha game - The Forest's combat, while a bit wonky (especially with player versus player) looks fine from first person; it seems heavy hitting, and brutal, with each of your hits knocking the cannibals back, occasionally knocking teeth out. And while the blocking system is currently a bit over powered (you literally can just hold the block button and take 0 damage from hits, provided you have the stamina), they are fixing it slowly; it can't be easy to make a game balanced. The AI acts exactly how you'd expect feral, animal like cannibals to strike at you. They run at you, hit once or twice, then back off because they're frightened of you. (Note this is for the ones that look like little Gollums.) 3: The Variety of Cannibals - This one is a bit of a list, but these tribes compete, and often fight. This also includes the fact that there are a finite number of cannibals in the Forest; they run out eventually.1 Starvers: These are the gollum lookin' dudes I was talking about. They are feral, creepy, and like to laugh maniacally. They are also weak, quick, and probably one of the easiest enemies in the game2 The White Cannibals?: Not sure what their real name is, but they are white skinned to the point of being pale as hell, they are one of the more civilised cannibal tribes, and will do the aforementioned out-checking of you (they're less hostile than the Starvers) They kinda look like aliens sometimes.3 The Brown Cannibals?: Also not sure; these look like normal humans, entirely, they are also more peaceful, and are fairly strong, along with the White Cannibals. 4 The Mutants: Ok here's where we get creepy; these are the huge, multi-limbed animals that like to smash your defenses, and are incredibly difficult to kill. You need fire to kill these bad boys. They come in two categories: The Virginia (Aka spider mutants, they have many legs and are quick, blind, and creepy as hell) and the Octopus Mutants: Which have many many arms, and are strong and chargy.5 Not sure if these deserve their own category, but they are incredibly creepy and sometimes kinda deadly: Mutant Babies. They are deformed monsters that jump at you, and make creepy noises. They are in caves solely. I might edit this to put in more cons as I see them, but for now the only real thing that they need to fix is the two world breaking bugs, the blocking system, and adding some more content as well as making boats actually viable. This game is great, but you might want to wait until it comes out.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ever since it's first early alpha release I have been obsessed with this game. The visuals and stunning the developers went above and beyond to create a living breathing forest atmosphere for players to explore. With simulated weather, altitites, wild life etc the game really immerses players into the island world.As a survival horror, this game takes player surival and believability seriously one of the most realistic survival games I've ever played. Players will be required to keep tabs on their hunger, temperature, thirst levels and infections to survive after their plane has crashed landed. Clean drinking water becomes the upmost importance for players as thirst is constantly going down, and most streams/ponds are poisoned.The game has an amazing crafting system and surivival book for notes and tips on how players can survive and what crafting options they have. Most people have likely already seen videos of the tree cutting, but guys, guys! YOU ACTUALLY CUT DOWN THE TREES. You fell them, with your tools and they fall. Brilliant. Seriously guys we've been gathering pixelated resources for years and trees have never actually fallen. Go buy this game! DO IT! Story mode is coming, but for now multiplayer survival horror is brilliant. If you aren't a fan of survival games, then maybe this isn't the game for you. You are literally stranded on an island so you spend a lot of time in nature trying not to die, which is challenging and rewarding but I can see how some people in this COD erra want more   'action'. There is combat and enemies in this game, but for most players the best strategie to to run, avoid, hide and build until you have a secure location to wage war.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								First let me start by saying this is EXACTLY how an Early Access game should work.- Devs regularly update.- Devs regularly bug fix and hotfix.- Devs listen to the suggestions of its community.- Game is not the price of a full release AAA game- No DLC in Early Access (sorry that was a little biased)Well done Endnight Games!Ok now on to the real review!Lets talk about the Pros of the game.- GraphicsFor an indie game in Early Access this game looks gorgeous. I find my self completely lost in the game, which it being a sort of horror/survival game makes it really shine.- CraftingIt has a very robust crafting system with plenty of things to craft: armor, weapons, fires, shelters, walls floors and roofs (more on this later), ect and in a simple, easy to understand way.- AI/EnemiesFirst of all let me say the enemies on this game really drive home the horror aspect of this game. Without going to far into details (I don't want to run all the fun ;-) ) expect very intelligent AI and even certain amounts of teamwork.- Horror aspectWhile I'm not really sure if I would call this the main aspect of the game, it has its scary moments. You are the one being hunted (at least early on) and not the other way around, it really does feel that way.- PriceThis maybe a big factor to some and not so much to others. First of let me tell you that even if no more updates were released (which is NOT the case), this game is absolutely worth the $15 purchasing price. This game has more content, polish, and stability (at least for single player, more on this later)  than a few games out on the market today.Now for some Cons!- Bugs and Multiplayer StabilityThis is an Early Access game that is in its Alpha phase. This shows in the amount of bugs and glitches that are present in the game. The worst offender of this would be multiplayer, which still has a few problems with host - client sync along with other small problem. That being said they are improving on this with every patch (which are very frequent) and they have already made tremendous progress on this front since I had originally purchased the game.- Lack of Complex BuildingIn this game you can build custom structures using floors, walls, platforms, stairs, ect. That being said what you can do with them is still somewhat limiting compared to some other survival games. This is something that they have said they will be improving on and I am very much look forward to it.- Ease of Late GameEarly on this game is quite challenging to new players; enemy attacks, food, water, and shelter needs can make this a challenging game and you may find yourself struggling to survive, which is exactly as it should be. However this is somewhat dulled down by how easy it becomes to survive the later you play and the better prepared you become. Enemies spawns and patrols do increase as time goes on, but if you are well prepared it becomes very easy to survive.Overall The Forest is an exceptional example of how an Early Access game should be made and an outstanding game overall. There are a few things the Devs can do to improve the game and I am very much looking forward to Endnight Games continued work on both this game and any games they work on in the future!I definitely recommend this game as both a single-player and multiplayer experience that you can pickup to enjoy now and continue to enjoy in the future.

Early Access Review
The Price Fair if you want to play a thriller and don't want to wait for a sale (I'd personaly wait for a sale). Specs./Computer Hardware If you have a weak PC/LapTop then you will more than likely not be able to run this game as it requires a descent set up, but you can play this game at a steady 35 fps. Content The principle of the game is simple: gather resources (water, food, lumber,etc.), build a house, and survive by killing the mutants but there are survivors being held hostage by the mutants that you can rescue (purely your choice).  There are many cheats you can try out to add more fun to the game.   Conclusion The game is great as it features great content and consistent updates; Ill give it a 4.75/5 stars

								Ever wanted to be in a plane crash???? NOW YOU CAN!!!! I give it a B minus.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am torn between whether to recommend this game or not. For £10.99 it may be worth having a look if you have money to splash around and you like survival horrors but otherwise there just isn't enough depth. The bugginess and ridiculously dark caves filled with op monsters and no save points will annoy the hell out of you.I have had this game for almost 2 years and it is still in alpha stage and looks set to stay there. Once you have seen the four corners of the forest, chopped down a few trees and died in a deep dark cave there really is nothing else left to do.The crafting system works well enough but the combat feels clunky, particulary the bow. The torch is next to useless. Aside from a few unique items there seems no real point in venturing into caves and constantly having to build fires because you fell into a pool will test your patience, wandering around in the dark for nothing just seems pointless.The atmosphere, however, is palpable. Having a cannibal appear out of the dark and scream at you is liable to require a new pair of under pants. But that soon wears thin.All in all a good attempt at survival horror but the developers need to finesse it into a game for the masses rather than a niche market for it to be recommended. If, however, survival horror is your thing then consider this recommended.

It doesn't play particulalry amazing.The options menu is somewhat lacking.Disapointing sound design and mixing.Ultimately, The Forest is not a bad game for someone who really like open world survival horror sandbox games, but if you're not well versedin the genre or don't get much enjoyment out of it, your money is better spent elsewhere.
